The study also found no correlation between the total cluster star formation rate normalized by cluster mass and cluster mass, indicating that cluster mechanisms that scale with mass, such as ram pressure and harassment, do not play a dominant role in regulating star formation in local clusters. The study used a sample of 69 clusters at redshift 0.1, and detected a total of 109 star-forming galaxies with specific star formation rates above 4.6 within 3 times the virial radius.

The text discusses the Bishop-Phelps-Bollobas theorem and its extension to bounded linear operators, known as the strong Bishop-Phelps-Bollobas property (SBPBP). The SBPBP is a generalization of the Bishop-Phelps-Bollobas theorem to operators, where a pair of Banach spaces has the SBPBP if there exists a positive real number such that whenever an operator attains its norm, there exists a vector such that the operator attains its norm at that vector. The text also introduces the uniform SBPBP, where the positive real number depends only on the norm of the operator. The text provides examples of pairs of Banach spaces that fail to have the uniform SBPBP, including the pair of spaces consisting of the real numbers with the supremum norm and the space of continuous functions on the closed unit interval with the supremum norm. The text also provides a complete characterization of the SBPBP for the pair of spaces consisting of the real numbers with the supremum norm and the space of continuous functions on the closed unit interval with the supremum norm.

The analysis of modern accelerator-based neutrino oscillation experiments requires a good understanding of the intermediate-energy neutrino-nucleus scattering cross section, with a particular focus on multi-nucleon events and two-particle-two-hole (2p-2h) excitations. A growing interest has arisen in including 2p-2h models into the Monte Carlo event generators used by neutrino collaborations. The only 2p-2h model currently implemented in some generators is the Valencia model, incorporated in GENIE. The main challenge in implementing these models is the high computational time due to the large number of nested integrals involved in the evaluation of the inclusive hadronic tensor. To address this, a fast and efficient method called the frozen nucleon approximation has been developed, which reduces the number of nested integrals from 7 to 1. This approach was first explored in a previous study but was restricted to the analysis of the 2p-2h phase space. Here, it is extended to the evaluation of the full hadronic tensor, assuming that the initial momenta of the two struck nucleons can be neglected for high enough energy and momentum transfer. The frozen nucleon approximation was found to work properly in computing the phase space function for two-particle emission in the range of momentum transfers of interest for neutrino experiments with accelerators. The validity of the frozen approximation beyond the phase-space study was investigated by including the electroweak meson-exchange current (MEC) model of Benhar et al. It was found that the presence of virtual delta excitations requires the introduction of a "frozen" @xmath1-propagator, designed by a convenient average over the Fermi sea. The main advantage of the frozen approximation is that it reduces the number of nested integrals needed to evaluate the inclusive 2p-2h electroweak responses from 7 to 1, making it well-suited for computing the 2p-2h neutrino cross sections folded with the neutrino flux. It can also be of great help in implementing the 2p-2h models in the Monte Carlo codes currently available.

<summary>
The paper presents optical spectroscopic and photometric observations of the low-luminosity AGN H 0507+164, obtained over a month-long reverberation mapping campaign. The source's continuum and Hβ line fluxes were found to vary, with a time lag of about 4 days between them. The size of the broad-line region was estimated to be around 1.5 parsecs, and the black hole mass was calculated to be approximately 10^6 solar masses. The measured time lag is consistent with the known R_L relationship. The study highlights the need for more reverberation mapping campaigns on low-luminosity AGNs to better understand their properties and evolution.
</summary>

<summary>
The broad emission iron lines in active galactic nuclei and black hole binaries are believed to originate from the accretion disc near the black hole, with the black hole's spin playing a crucial role in their formation. The Laor model, which assumes a maximally rotating Kerr black hole, has been widely used, but newer models like the Ky model allow the spin to be fitted. The aim of the paper is to compare the Laor and Ky models using data from the XMM-Newton satellite and simulated data for the upcoming XEUS mission. Two sources, MCG-6-30-15 and GX 339-4, known for their extremely skewed iron lines, were chosen for this study. The Ky model provided better constraints on the spin parameter and more regularly shaped confidence contour plots, indicating a smoother adjustment between different points in the parameter space. However, for the current data, the discrepancies between the two models were within the general uncertainties of spin determination using the skewed line profile. For higher quality data, like those simulated for the XEUS mission, the differences between the models were more apparent, with the Laor model tending to overestimate the spin value and having insufficient energy resolution. The correct re-binning of the data with respect to the instrumental energy resolution was found to be crucial for obtaining statistically relevant results.
</summary>

The article presents a method to generate static disks made of perfect fluid using the "displace, cut, and reflect" technique on static spheres of perfect fluid in isotropic coordinates. The disks have radial and azimuthal pressures equal to the surface energy density, and the sound velocity is less than the speed of light. The disks are generated from various exact solutions of the Einstein field equations, including the Schwarzschild, Buchdahl, and Narlikar-Patwardhan-Vaidya (NPV) solutions. The disks can be surrounded by a halo of perfect fluid matter, and the physical quantities of the disks are calculated using the metric coefficients and the Einstein field equations. The disks have surface energy density and pressures that decrease monotonically with radius, and the tangential velocity of test particles in circular motion first increases with radius and then decreases. The disks can be stable or have regions of unstable circular orbits, depending on the parameters chosen.

The paper presents a theoretical investigation of two-component Bose-Einstein condensates (BEC) with a coupling drive, focusing on the existence and stability of a domain wall configuration where the relative phase between the two condensates changes by π. The domain wall is shown to be a local minimum of the energy, but not a global minimum, and can decay by quantum tunneling or thermal activation over an energy barrier. The decay rate is exponentially suppressed, and the domain wall can be bounded by a vortex line.

The text discusses the phenomenon of anomalies in quantum field theory, focusing on gravitational anomalies in two dimensions. It introduces the method of dispersion relations as a useful approach to determine anomalies, which are typically associated with the breakdown of symmetries in the quantum theory. The text also mentions the equivalence of the dispersion relation approach and the dimensional regularization procedure, and the calculation of gravitational schwinger terms using a dispersive approach adapted from a method by Klln. The anomalies and schwinger terms are shown to have a peculiar infrared feature, with the imaginary part of the relevant formfactor approaching a delta function singularity at zero momentum squared. The text concludes by noting the practical simplicity of the method in two dimensions, but the increased complexity in higher dimensions.

<summary>STE-QUEST is a proposed European Space Agency (ESA) mission to test Einstein's Equivalence Principle (EEP) using two instruments: an atomic clock and an atom interferometer. The mission aims to measure gravitational redshift, compare distant ground clocks, and test the weak equivalence principle. The spacecraft will be launched into a highly elliptical orbit, with perigee at 700 km and apogee at 50,000 km. The mission will use both microwave and optical links for precise time and frequency transfer. The spacecraft will be powered by solar arrays and will use chemical and micro-propulsion systems for attitude control and de-orbiting. The mission is complex and requires a ground segment with three ground terminals and highly accurate ground clocks. The assessment study identified several challenges, including low maturity of certain payload components, potential unavailability of sufficiently accurate ground clocks, high sensitivity of optical links to atmospheric distortions, and high energy dissipation of the instruments. However, the mission design is compliant with the challenging demands made by the payload on performance and resources.</summary>

<summary>
The text discusses the use of high-frequency electromagnetic waves to study the ionosphere, with a focus on parametric instabilities and secondary radiation. It mentions previous experiments and simulations, and introduces a new full-scale simulation study of an HF electromagnetic wave propagating into the ionosphere with realistic parameters. The simulation shows the reflection of the left-hand and right-hand circularly polarized modes at different altitudes, mode conversion of the left-hand mode into electrostatic waves, and nonlinear harmonic generation. The study suggests that such simulations can become a powerful tool for quantitative studies of HF-induced ionospheric turbulence and secondary radiation.
</summary>

The article presents a study of the short-range correlations in a bosonic Mott-Hubbard model using perturbation theory, focusing on the corrections to the one-particle density matrix and its relevance to experimentally observed expansion patterns. The model describes a system of cold bosonic atoms in an optical lattice, and the Mott-Hubbard model is used to capture the essential physics of the system. The authors use Rayleigh-Schrödinger perturbation theory to improve the mean-field solution obtained from the Gutzwiller ansatz, including corrections up to second order. The study finds important modifications to single-site observables and the correlation function, with the perturbative approach providing a better description of the short-range behavior of the one-particle density matrix. The results have implications for the expansion patterns of both bulk systems and a harmonic confining potential, with the inclusion of short-range correlations leading to distinct modifications in the momentum distributions.

The text discusses a method for classifying and visualizing homogeneous isotropic cosmologies in multi-scalar models with an arbitrary scalar potential. The method involves augmenting the target space parametrized by the scalar fields to a larger space of lorentzian signature, with the logarithm of the scale factor playing the role of time. This augmented target space has a lorentzian metric, and cosmological trajectories correspond to geodesics in this space. The text also discusses the acceleration of cosmologies and introduces the concept of an acceleration cone within the lightcone of the augmented target space.

<summary>
The paper presents new photometry and preliminary trigonometric parallax astrometry for a faint, red star (LSPM J2322+7847) found to be a potential common proper motion companion to the active and rapidly rotating G9V star Hip 115147 (BD+78 826, HD 220140, V368 Cep). Hip 115147 is a young, post-T Tauri dwarf with high levels of chromospheric and coronal activity, and is part of the Local Association, which limits its age to around 20 million years. The photometric data and parallax measurements suggest that the triple system (Hip 115147, Hip 115147b, and LSPM J2322+7847) is likely around 50 million years old, with the faintest component (LSPM J2322+7847) having an estimated mass of about 0.5 solar masses. The star Hip 115147 is believed to have originated from the LDN 1709 molecular cloud in the Ophiuchus star-forming region, but its probable age based on this origin is 16 million years, which contradicts the isochrone analysis and lithium abundance. The proper motion difference between Hip 115147 and LSPM J2322+7847 may indicate that they are not gravitationally bound, but more accurate proper motions and radial velocities are needed to confirm this. The research was carried out at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under a contract with NASA, and used data from the Simbad database and 2MASS.
</summary>

<summary>
The universe's flatness and accelerating expansion, driven by dark energy, have led to the exploration of its connection with particle physics. The Mavans model introduces an "acceleron" scalar field and neutrino interactions through a new scalar force. The neutrino mass depends on the acceleron and evolves with the universe. The model's scalar potential and neutrino mass evolution depend on the potential's form. This work presents a supersymmetric Mavans model with gravity-mediated supersymmetry breaking, showing evolutions of neutrino mass and the equation of state parameter. In this model, a chiral superfield in the dark sector causes cosmic acceleration, and supersymmetry breaking occurs in the hidden sector. Two cases are considered: vanishing and finite mixing between left-handed and sterile neutrinos. In the vanishing mixing case, only the sterile neutrino mass varies, and the neutrino-acceleron fluid is hydrodynamically stable. In the finite mixing case, both neutrino masses vary slightly, and the model remains stable.
</summary>

The Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP) is a phase of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) where quarks and gluons are liberated from hadrons. The study of the QGP phase transition is a central aim in the field of hot and dense QCD.

<summary>
A conformally symmetric model for strong interactions at low energies was proposed, based on Weyl's observation that gauge theories retain their flat-space-time form under a conformally flat metric. Quarks and gluons are confined through two scalar fields that break the symmetry, and a symmetric second-order tensor field serves as the metric for flat space-time. The model describes quarks and gluons oscillating inside a closed universe, and photons freely traveling through flat space-time. The fields comprise one real scalar and one complex scalar, with the real scalar associated with confinement and the complex scalar with electromagnetism. Weak interactions were not considered in the original model, but electroweak unification can be inferred. The model's main property is flavor-independent oscillations, observed in mesonic resonances. An apparent interference effect around 38 MeV was observed in BABAR data, suggesting the existence of a light scalar particle. This particle, designated as the σ(38), is a candidate for the scalar boson related to confinement and may consist of a mini-universe filled with glue, forming a very light scalar glueball. The BABAR collaboration is urged to inspect their larger data set to confirm the existence of the σ(38) and related hybrid spectrum.
</summary>

The paper introduces the concept of stochastic resonance, where adding noise to a signal can improve its transmission and detection. The authors study this phenomenon in the context of estimating a constant, non-negative signal below a threshold, using two observation schemes: time spent over the threshold and energy of the signal above the threshold. They consider an ergodic diffusion process as the noise structure and analyze the problem in continuous time. The paper presents two different estimators for each scheme and investigates their asymptotic properties. An example is provided where stochastic resonance is observed, and the paper also solves a hypothesis testing problem using the Bayesian maximum a posteriori probability criterion, showing that the overall probability of error is non-monotonically dependent on the noise level.

The order parameter in high-temperature superconductors has been proven to have mainly a d-wave pairing symmetry, with a predominant d-wave gap symmetry up to the superconducting critical temperature. Thermal transport measurements have shown the predominance of this symmetry for the gap function, with a fourfold oscillation in the longitudinal thermal conductivity when a magnetic field is rotated parallel to the CuO2 planes, which can be explained by Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices and Doppler shift in the energy spectrum of the quasiparticles. However, the fourfold oscillation has not been resolved above 7 K, and deviations from the expected angular pattern within a pure d-wave symmetry have been attributed to the effect of pinning of vortices. The thermal activation of quasiparticles with increasing temperature, treated phenomenologically within a Fermi liquid approximation for thermal transport including the d-wave gap function, can explain the experimental results in the whole temperature range, including the change of symmetry of the order parameter as a function of temperature.

<summary>
The paper studies Dehn surgery on knots in 3-manifolds, focusing on purely cosmetic surgeries where the resulting manifolds are homeomorphic. It introduces a knot invariant, denoted as W3, and proves that if a knot has either W3(1) or W3(2) non-zero, then it does not admit purely cosmetic surgeries. This result is an improvement of a previous result by Boyer and Lines, which considered knots with non-zero normalized Alexander polynomial. The paper also lists all knots with no more than 10 crossings that do not admit purely cosmetic surgeries, except possibly for one knot. Additionally, it proves that certain families of two-bridge knots and Whitehead doubles do not admit purely cosmetic surgeries.
</summary>

<summary>
Anomaly-mediated supersymmetry breaking (AMSB) models have attractive features like calculable soft terms, real and flavor invariant, and renormalization group invariant. However, they suffer from tachyonic slepton masses, which can be resolved by adding a universal scalar mass. The minimal AMSB (mAMSB) model has parameters m_0, m_3/2, sign(μ), and the alternative hypercharged AMSB (HCAMSB) model uses a string-motivated setup with similar sequestering. HCAMSB models have a different parameter space given by m_0, m_3/2, tan(β), sign(μ), and can be distinguished from mAMSB at the LHC due to the presence of stau candidates in cascade decay events. The LHC reach for HCAMSB models is up to 1.05 TeV for small tan(β) and 1.08 TeV for large tan(β).
</summary>

The paper introduces the concept of dressing the zero-range potential (ZRP) model using Darboux transformations (DT) to improve its capabilities. The ZRP is conventionally represented as a boundary condition on the wavefunction, while DT allows for the construction of exactly solvable potentials. The authors use DT to modify the generalized ZRP boundary condition, creating a potential with arbitrarily disposed discrete spectrum levels for any angular momentum. They also consider a multi-centered potential that includes ZRPs and apply DT to dress it. As an example, they study electron scattering by the CO2 and N2O structures within the framework of the ZRP model and discuss their calculations.

The text discusses the numerical solution of a convection-diffusion equation using the Differential Quadrature Method (DQM) with modified cubic B-splines as base functions. The method is used to transform the convection-diffusion problem into a system of first-order ordinary differential equations (ODEs) in time, which is then solved using the Strong Stability Preserving - Runge-Kutta 5(4) (SSP-RK54) scheme. The accuracy and adaptability of the method are demonstrated through three test problems. The proposed solutions are found to be more accurate than those obtained by various existing schemes and are in good agreement with the exact solutions. The order of accuracy of the proposed methods for the convection-diffusion problem with Dirichlet boundary conditions is cubic in space, while for Neumann boundary conditions, it is quadratic with respect to the L2 error norm. The methods are found to be stable for two-dimensional convection-diffusion equations using matrix stability analysis.

The text discusses a sample of bright submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) selected using SCUBA and MAMBO images of the Lockman Hole region. The sample consists of 19 SMGs, 15 of which are detected securely by deep radio imaging. The authors determine 15 spectroscopic redshifts, with 10 considered secure. The resulting redshift distribution is consistent with that determined by Chapman et al. (2005) for a much larger sample. The authors conclude that the bright SMG population is readily amenable to study via radio-selected samples, down to a 850-μm flux density limit of 3.5 mJy.

The authors present an analysis of the luminosity function (LF) of galaxies in the Norris survey of the Corona Borealis supercluster. They find that the LF of local field galaxies, when normalized to counts in high galactic latitude fields, agrees well with the Las Campanas Redshift Survey (LCRS). However, the normalization of their @xmath6 local LF is roughly a factor of 1.6 higher than that of the Stromlo/APM survey, suggesting a systematic photometry error in one or more of the surveys. The mean color of local Norris galaxies is that of an Sb galaxy, while the mean color of LCRS galaxies is that of an E galaxy, indicating that the error is likely in the APM catalog. The authors observe evolution of the field galaxy LF within their sample, confirming previous redshift surveys' conclusions. The evolution is limited to the population of blue, star-forming galaxies, which become more luminous with increasing redshift. The population of blue galaxies exhibits spectral signatures of ongoing star formation at higher redshifts, but the star formation is long-lived, not short-term bursts. The LF of galaxies with weak [OII] emission does not show significant evolution. The LFs of the two superclusters show differences from the field galaxy LF, likely due to environmental effects. The most prominent difference is an excess of very bright galaxies in the superclusters, found in dense regions and dominated by an old, red stellar population. The characteristic magnitude @xmath102 is @xmath210 brighter in the Corona Borealis supercluster than in the field, but not in the Abell 2069 supercluster. There is also suggestive evidence of a sharp upturn in the supercluster LF for @xmath215.

<summary>
The text discusses the observation of rapidity gaps in hadronic collisions at the Tevatron, attributed to color singlet exchange between incident partons. The two-gluon exchange model predicts a gap fraction of about 1%, but recent measurements by the CDF and D0 collaborations show no decrease in the gap fraction with increasing jet transverse momentum, casting doubt on this model. The authors reconsider the model and demonstrate its limitations, showing that even starting from a perturbative picture, determining the color singlet exchange fraction is essentially nonperturbative. They find that the one- and two-gluon exchange amplitudes are too large to be compatible with unitarity, and phase shift unitarization leads to a more realistic description with different color singlet exchange fractions. The authors then perform a numerical analysis with running coupling constant and find that the predicted color singlet fractions strongly depend on the regularization of gluon exchange at small momentum transfer, making reliable perturbative calculations impossible. Within their unitarized model, non-perturbative effects can be summarized in terms of two parameters: the survival probability of gaps and a universal Coulomb phase shift. The authors analyze implications for gap formation at the Tevatron, calculating how the gap fraction between two hard jets varies with jet transverse energies and pseudorapidity separation, and compare predicted fractions with Tevatron data.
</summary>

<summary>
The text discusses the importance of electric energy consumption forecasting for operators, consumers, and system security. It reviews various approaches, including time series, functional-based, and soft computing-based methods, with a focus on artificial neural networks (ANN). The study presents an ANN model for forecasting energy consumption in the Gaza Strip using historical data from 1994 to 2013, with the model's performance evaluated using mean squared error (MSE), root mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE). The results show that the ANN model can accurately predict future trends of electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip.
</summary>

Low mass x-ray binaries (LMXBs) are compact binaries where the primary is a compact object and the secondary is a low mass star. The secondary transfers mass via Roche-lobe overflow, forming an accretion disk around the compact object that gives rise to the observed x-rays. LMCX-2 is a persistent LMXB that shows the properties of a z-source, suggesting a high accretion rate and a neutron star primary. The optical counterpart of LMCX-2 was identified in 1978, but little is known about the system parameters. The orbital period of LMCX-2 has been estimated to range from 6.4 hours to 12 days, but no periodic variability was detected in 6 years of MACHO data. A new technique developed by Steeghs & Casares (2002) has been used to detect a signature of the donor star in persistent LMXBs, including LMCX-2. The technique involves phase-resolved spectroscopy and the detection of narrow emission lines in the Bowen region, which are interpreted as coming from the irradiated side of the donor star. This discovery allows for the first constraints on the system parameters of LMCX-2, including a mass function and possible mass ratio. The radial velocity curve of the HeII emission line shows a periodic variability that is interpreted as the orbital period, but the semi-amplitude and mean velocity may have changed during the second night of observations. The doppler maps of the HeII and Bowen regions show emission features that may be related to a precessing accretion disk in LMCX-2. The narrow emission lines in the Bowen region suggest that the compact spot is produced on the donor star, but the low velocities in the HeII doppler maps may indicate that the accretion disk is inclined. The mass function and mass ratio of LMCX-2 are constrained using the velocity of the Bowen spot and the width of the narrow emission lines. The mass ratio is further constrained by the presence of a precessing accretion disk in LMCX-2. The system parameters of LMCX-2 are still not tightly constrained, but a long-term spectroscopic campaign could provide more accurate measurements.

The text discusses the axial anomaly in quantum field theory, its interpretation as an infrared phenomenon, and its connection to the breaking of chiral symmetry. The author extends the Dolgov and Zakharov approach to study the radiative pion decay, focusing on the case where the outgoing lepton undergoes an helicity flip and interpreting its behavior in the chiral limit as a manifestation of the axial anomaly.

<summary>
The text discusses the challenges and recent progress in the field of salient object detection in computer vision. It highlights the need for more versatile datasets and remedies biases in existing datasets, particularly the lack of background clutter and the number of objects. The text mentions several popular datasets and their properties, and notes that recent efforts to extend existing datasets have not adequately addressed these core issues. The text also discusses the relationship between fixations and saliency judgments, and introduces two new benchmark datasets, Bruce-A and Judd-A, which challenge existing state-of-the-art models. The text proposes a simple baseline salient object detection model and compares it to eight state-of-the-art methods on these datasets. The text concludes that the proposed model outperforms other models on the new datasets and highlights the main reason behind the failure of models on complex scenes, which is segmenting the wrong object as the most salient one.
</summary>

The text describes an algorithm to construct a nice triple heegaard diagram for a cobordism consisting of two-handle additions. The algorithm involves modifying a given doubly pointed heegaard diagram to make a knot embedded in the surface, adding twin gamma curves for each beta curve, and then stabilizing the diagram to obtain a triple heegaard diagram representing the cobordism. The algorithm can be extended to cobordisms consisting of several two-handles by viewing them as surgery along a link and using a multi-pointed heegaard diagram to describe the link. The algorithm ensures that the resulting triple heegaard diagram is nice, meaning that all unpunctured elementary domains are either bigons or rectangles.

The text discusses the deformation theory of pasting diagrams of @xmath0-linear categories, functors, and natural transformations. It introduces a method developed by Shreshtha for encoding cocycle conditions, obstruction formulas, and cobounding conditions using polygons and systems of parallels. The text then applies this method to show that obstructions to deformations are cocycles for certain pasting diagrams, including those with a single composition of natural transformations or functors, and for certain diagrams in which specified cells are deformed trivially.

<summary>
The aim of physics is not just to calculate observable quantities but to understand the underlying physical phenomena. In complex systems like crystals and QCD, it's essential to identify the relevant degrees of freedom. In QCD, the relevant degrees of freedom at low energies are constituent quarks and mesons, not current quarks and gluons. The spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry is the most important QCD phenomenon for understanding nucleon mass and low-energy properties. This leads to the appearance of pseudoscalar mesons and the acquisition of dynamical mass by quarks. Constituent quarks interact via the exchange of Goldstone bosons (pseudoscalar mesons), vector and scalar mesons, and are subject to confinement. The spin-spin interaction between constituent quarks is crucial for baryon properties, while the net tensor and spin-orbit interactions are weak. The chiral constituent quark model successfully describes both non-strange and strange baryon spectra. The short-range repulsion in the nucleon-nucleon interaction can be explained by the same short-range part of the chiral interaction that produces hyperfine splittings in baryon spectroscopy.</summary>

The invention relates to implantable medical devices with a calcium phosphate coating that is biocompatible, bio-resorbable, and capable of storing and releasing medicinally active agents in a controlled manner. The calcium phosphate coating is deposited on the device using a sol-gel process, which allows for control of the coating's crystallinity, bonding, and porosity characteristics. The coating is thin and flexible, allowing it to withstand deformation without damage or spallation. The calcium phosphate coating can be hydroxyapatite, dicalcium phosphate, tricalcium phosphate, or tetracalcium phosphate, and can be deposited on various metallic substrates, such as stainless steel, cobalt alloy, titanium, or metallic alloy. The device can be a human or animal tissue implantable device, such as a stent.

<summary>
The present invention provides nerve guidance conduits (NGCs) with integrated spiral structured porous sheets decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers for enhanced nerve regeneration and repair. These NGCs have superior mechanical strength, multiple channels for cell-cell interaction, stable aligned fibrous layers, high surface/volume ratios, and chambers at the ends for reduced tension during suturing. The NGCs are tunable in size and can be used for long gap repair/regeneration. In vitro and in vivo studies demonstrate the NGCs' potential for nerve regeneration and functional recovery, comparable to or even better than autografts.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention provides new rail connectors for furniture seat base support assemblies, including sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, and flexible steel bands. The connectors offer four essential seat-force-generators: torsioning, dynamic uplift, expansion-contraction, and leverage-amplification. They produce four desired seat-performance characteristics: initial-drop, deep-drop, softness without defects, and resilient uplift proportionate to load. Two forms of connectors are disclosed: one using pre-stressed, close-wound coil springs with attachment arms, and another using a pre-stressed, cantilever spring configuration. The connectors can be used with various seat base support means and provide dynamic uplift adjacent the back rail, similar to a de-arced sinuous spring band.
</summary>

The present disclosure is directed to an anvil assembly for a circular surgical stapling device, including a stabilizing collet positioned within the anvil shaft to prevent damage to the anvil assembly during attachment to the stapling device. The anvil shaft has a proximal portion with flexible legs defining a longitudinal bore, and the collet is supported within this bore to protect the flexible legs from excessive pressure applied by a grasper. The collet is substantially rigid and has a distal end with cantilevered fingers that secure the collet within the anvil shaft, allowing the anvil assembly to be reliably attached to the stapling device.

<summary>
The present invention provides a container for a blender with a rigid lining inside the cup to shield the inner wall from collisions and to grind fibers of vegetables and fruits using teeth projected from the inner wall of the lining. The lining can be made of metal, glass, or other rigid materials and can be shaped as a half-mask or a whole-mask. The lining can be combined with the cup by injection molding or as separate prefabricated components. The lining has vertical ribs and stopper members that correspond to each other, with the ribs being received into the hollowed troughs of the stopper members. The lining can also have teeth projected up from the top end of the stopper members. The lining can be shaped as a half-mask with a lip or horizontal ring extended from the top rim, or as a whole-mask with a horizontal ring. The lining can be formed as an integral annular lining or as a number of lining pieces combined to form an annular lining. The first facet of the stopper member can have a buckled piece that leads into a groove defined on the first facet of the rib, while the second facet of the lining pieces leads directly into a trench defined on the second facet of the rib of the cup.
</summary>

The invention relates to a garnish pick with one or more appendages, at least some of which may serve as skewering shafts for holding a garnish and/or as hooks for securing the garnish pick to a food or beverage container. The appendages may project from a main shaft at various angles and orientations, and may be curved, twisted, or otherwise contoured to resemble natural objects. The garnish pick may be made of various materials, such as wood, plastic, or metal, and may have a total length of approximately 2 to 5 inches and a maximum diameter of 15 cm. The garnish pick may have advantages over conventional picks, such as preventing the pick from becoming submerged in a beverage and making it easier to eat garnishes off of the pick.

The present invention is a device and algorithm for a combined cardiomyostimulator and cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator, designed to provide cardiac assistance during arrhythmias while ensuring prompt detection and diagnosis. During normal sinus rhythm, the device delivers skeletal muscle stimulation and bradycardia stimulation as needed. Upon detection of a sequence of cardiac events with intervals less than the tachycardia detection interval (TDI), the device inhibits skeletal muscle stimulation and enters a ventricular tachycardia (VT) counting mode. Similarly, upon detection of intervals less than the fibrillation detection interval (FDI), the device inhibits skeletal muscle stimulation and enters a ventricular fibrillation (VF) counting mode. While in these counting modes, the device counts the number of events meeting the respective criteria. Once the cumulative event counter equals the number of intervals to detect (VTNID or VFNID), the device delivers the appropriate therapy (VT or VF) and enters a VT/VF termination detection state. If the device detects VT or VF during this state, it returns to the relevant therapy state. If not, it returns to normal sinus rhythm. The device also features skeletal muscle stimulation during capacitor charging for defibrillation, which helps maintain cardiac perfusion and limits the increase in defibrillation thresholds.

The intraocular lens (IOL) device comprises a first lens with a pair of opposing and deformable surfaces and a cavity defined therebetween, a second lens in spaced relation to the first lens, and a circumferential haptic coupling the first and second lenses. The IOL device is resiliently biased to an unaccommodated state having a first diameter d1 in the absence of radial compressive forces exerted on the outer peripheral edge, and actuates to an accommodated state characterized by a second diameter d2 in response to radial compressive forces exerted on the outer peripheral edge, wherein d1 >d2. The first lens is a biconvex lens, the cavity is fully enclosed, and the IOL further comprises a gel in the cavity having a refractive index of 1.46 or greater and a Young's modulus of 10 psi or less. The second lens is one of a plano-convex lens, a bi-convex lens, and a positive meniscus lens, and is substantially more rigid than the first lens. The IOL further comprises a hinge disposed between the circumferential haptic and the second lens, which directs a substantial portion of the compressive forces onto the first lens to cause a greater proportionate reduction in the first lens diameter to be reduced proportionately than in the second lens diameter. Each of the opposing and deformable surfaces of the first lens has a thickness that is 50% or less of the second lens, and the IOL further comprises one or both of a plurality of apertures disposed on the circumferential haptic and a circumferential channel defined within the circumferential haptic. The plurality of apertures may be in fluid communication with the main IOL cavity, and the plurality of apertures may be in fluid communication with both the circumferential channel and the main IOL cavity. The IOL device further comprises a plurality of raised bumps, wherein at least one of the plurality of raised bumps is positioned adjacent to each one of the plurality of apertures, and a plurality of troughs, at least one of the plurality of troughs extending radially inward from each one of the plurality of apertures to facilitate fluid flow into the apertures. The circumferential haptic comprises a plurality of radial arms coupling the second lens, the plurality of radial arms defining apertures therebetween to permit fluid communication with the main cavity, and a third circumferential cavity disposed peripherally of the main IOL cavity. The opposing surfaces of the first lens are displaced away from each other upon the application of a radial force along the circumferential haptic, the opposing surfaces comprising central and

The invention is an esophageal-stomach displacement electrode for use in medical procedures like pacing or defibrillation. It consists of a semi-rigid plastic tube with an electrode at the distal end, inserted into the stomach via the esophagus. The tube has a crimped hinge that allows it to bend, and a displacement mechanism inside it. This mechanism includes a rigid pin with cords attached to its ends, one of which exits the tube through a port and re-enters through another port proximal to the hinge. Pulling the cord attached to the distal end of the pin causes the tube to bend at the hinge, displacing the electrode closer to the heart. The tube can be further displaced or pulled back to create a bulge in the stomach wall, placing the electrode even closer to the heart. The control mechanism at the proximal end of the tube operates the displacement mechanism by taking up one cord and playing out the other.

The game is a board game simulating life at a lake, with players moving tokens along a path and acquiring, selling, and improving lake areas, boat dealerships, and dams. The game includes Makin A Wake and Sunken Chest cards that offer benefits, penalties, or instructions, and players can roll doubles to move again or go to jail. The objective is to force other players into bankruptcy by accumulating wealth and property, with the last player remaining being declared the winner.

The invention provides an apparatus and method for treating and regenerating tissues using a dressing system that combines fluid supply and suction drainage. The apparatus includes a vertically movable rest for positioning a fluid bag at the level of the wound, a drip chamber with an angulated entry channel for visual drop count, and an injection port for administering intermittent doses of saline or drug solution during ongoing suctioning. The dressing pad may include an open grid at the drainage port to prevent occlusion of the underlying open pores. The apparatus also includes a device for detecting bleeding from the wound during continuous suctioning treatment.

The invention is a gravity-driven, steerable vehicle designed for downhill racing or riding, with a prone, face-down riding position. It has at least two wheels or skis, a steering system, and a braking system. The vehicle can be retrofitted with skis or a combination of skis and wheels for use on snow-covered terrain. The suspension system is configured to provide precise control in turns, especially the carving of turns by the skis on snow-covered surfaces.

The present invention relates to an imaging method and apparatus employing Radial Reflection Diffraction Tomography (RRDT) for improved imaging of objects, such as vulnerable plaque in arteries or buried wastes in boreholes. The method involves directing energy waves radially outward from a probe and receiving scattered waves from objects, with the received data processed using a wave-based algorithm to map angular location and frequency parameters to construct images. The apparatus includes a flexible substrate with one or more elements capable of directing and receiving energy waves, and a Hilbert space inverse wave (HSIW) algorithm for processing the collected data. The invention can be used for intravascular imaging, borehole characterization, and other non-destructive evaluation applications.

The biological oil composition of the present invention, derived from the marine copepod Calanus finmarchicus, has been shown to have a significant ability to inhibit the formation of atherosclerotic plaques in mice, unlike concentrated EPA/DHA preparations. The copepod oil also has a significant effect on reducing total blood cholesterol levels in mice, compared to both control and EPA/DHA-treated groups. The copepod oil composition comprises 20-100% by weight of wax esters, 5-20% by weight of SDA, 3-15% by weight of EPA, and 2-10% by weight of DHA. The oil composition is useful in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease, atherosclerosis, hypercholesterolaemia, and elevated blood cholesterol levels.

The invention relates to pharmaceutical compositions containing polyelectrolyte complexes in microparticulate form and at least one active substance. The active substance can be embedded in the matrix of the polyelectrolyte complex, be a partner in the complex, or be bound to a partner of the complex. The polyelectrolyte complexes are composed of biocompatible, biodegradable polyacids and polybases, which are naturally occurring or composed of natural subunits. Preferred polyacids include xylan polysulfate, partially hydrophobically esterified xylan polysulfate, polysulfates of other polysaccharides, poly(amino acids) such as polyaspartic acid or polyglutamic acid, and their hydrophobically substituted derivatives. Preferred polybases include poly-L-lysine, poly-α,β-(2-dimethylaminoethyl)-D,L-aspartamide (PDAA), copolymers of PDAA and hydrophobically esterified poly-α,β-(2-hydroxyethyl)-D,L-aspartamide (PHEA), chitosan, lysine octadecyl ester, aminated dextrans, aminated cyclodextrins, aminated cellulose ethers, aminated pectins, and their partially hydrophobized derivatives. The incorporation of an active substance in the polyelectrolyte complex particles can be carried out by entrapment, absorption, chemical binding, or by employing the active substance as a partner in the formation of the polyelectrolyte complex. The particle size can be controlled by various parameters and can be adjusted from a few nm up to a few hundred μm. The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can be used as long-term systems for peptide-based active substances, as wound ointment preparations, or as air-containing echogenic contrast agents for ultrasonic diagnosis. The release of active substances from the microparticles can be controlled via the composition of the complex and can be adjusted to meet various requirements.

<summary>
The invention is a golf ball teeing device that allows users, especially those with mobility issues, to easily insert a golf tee into the ground with a golf ball on top without bending over. The device consists of a housing that clamps the ball and tee together using a delayed urging means, which is slightly compressed when the ball and tee are inserted, and further compresses when the tee is pushed into the ground, automatically releasing the ball and tee. The device can be attached to the end of a golf club grip, using the club as a handle, and can also be used to retrieve tees from the ground. It is lightweight, portable, and can be clipped onto a golfer's apparel or bag.
</summary>

<summary>
The present disclosure provides a person support apparatus with a mechanism for adjusting the height and orientation of a patient support frame. The apparatus includes a person support frame with two sides extending between a head end and a foot end, and a support assembly for moving the frame relative to a floor surface. The support assembly comprises at least one leg assembly pivotally coupled at an upper end to the frame and coupled at a lower end to floor engaging means, and an actuator element to move the leg assembly. At least one side of the frame comprises an inverted substantially U-shaped channel element with a continuous upper surface, two continuous side surfaces, and a downward facing opening. The upper end of the leg assembly includes a guide or follower element arranged to contact and run along an inner surface of the channel element. The apparatus can raise or lower the frame while keeping it substantially parallel to the floor, or move it into Trendelenburg or reverse Trendelenburg positions. The channel element has a lower part count, reduced risk of dirt interference, lower force requirement for lifting, and reduced risk of finger trapping compared to known systems. The channel element can also serve as a fixing area for accessories or other elements. The apparatus may include a braking mechanism for the castors, which can be actuated by contact with the underside of the channel element as the bed is lowered. The braking surfaces of the head end castors can be connected to the foot end braking levers by a rod element running inside each of the lower rail elements. The apparatus is suitable for hospital or long-term care beds and can accommodate changes in geometry necessary for movement or adjustment between horizontal, Trendelenburg, and reverse Trendelenburg positions.
</summary>

The invention relates to a skin reflectance measuring apparatus that uses a probe connected to a measuring device via a flexible connection in fiber optics. The probe has a casing with an aperture that faces the skin, and three optical conductors secured in the casing. The first and second conductors are directed in symmetrical directions with respect to an axis extending normally through the aperture, while the third conductor is directed in another direction. The measuring device includes light emitting means optically coupled to the first conductor, light receiving means optically coupled to the second and third conductors to produce signals representing specular and diffuse reflection, and processing means to compensate for variations in emitted light and ambient light. The processing means produces a relative reflectance signal from the measured values of specular and diffuse reflection, which is displayed on a display device. The apparatus is designed to measure reflectance on small surfaces, such as those less than 1 cm2, and can tolerate a few degrees of deviation in relative position between the probe and the skin surface. The apparatus can be used in pathology and cosmetology to measure the rate of secretion of sebum, study skin diseases, and test the efficiency of anti-reflectance products for greasy skins.

The invention is a dental cleaning and massaging apparatus consisting of a mouthpiece with upper and lower channel members that fit over the teeth and snugly against the gums. The channel members are joined by membranes and contain bite blocks to keep the teeth in place. Air-sacks along a hose between the channel members inflate and deflate to massage the gums, while water or cleaning fluid is pumped through the mouthpiece to clean the teeth and gums. The apparatus can be operated in three modes: air and water, air only, or water only, controlled by switches on the control box or a remote control device.

The present invention relates to pelvic floor reconstruction using implants. An anterior implant is used for reconstructing the anterior pelvic floor, including prolapse of the urinary bladder and/or the colon and the small intestine, while a posterior implant is used for reconstructing the posterior pelvic floor, including prolapse of the colon, the small intestine and/or the uterus. A needle is used for threading straps of the implants through ligaments, allowing the surgeon to thread the straps from the accessible side of the tissue without requiring any additional perforations of the body from the opposing direction. The needle includes a trap for trapping the strap to the needle, a tip for threading the trapped strap from the accessible side to the opposing side, and a mechanism for releasing the trap, driven from the accessible side of the tissue, allowing the tip to return to the accessible side of the tissue while abandoning the strap at the threaded point.

The first embodiment of the apparatus is designed to simultaneously achieve three goals: matching the phase and degree of assistance to the subject's spontaneous efforts when ventilation is well above a target ventilation, automatically adjusting the degree of assistance to maintain at least a specified minimum average ventilation without relying on the integrity of the subject's chemoreflexes, and providing some immunity to the effects of sudden leaks. The apparatus measures respiratory airflow and calculates the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle as a continuous variable using fuzzy logic. It then calculates a desired instantaneous delivery pressure as a function of the instantaneous phase and sets the delivered pressure to the subject to the desired delivery pressure. The apparatus also includes a fuzzy logic algorithm to detect and handle sudden changes in leak, and a servo-control system to adjust the degree of assistance to maintain at least a specified minimum average ventilation.

The invention is an electro-surgical dissecting and cauterizing instrument used primarily in endoscopic procedures. It consists of a proximal end with an electric plug for connection to an electro-surgical unit, a rigid, linear insulating sleeve, and a distal end with an electrically conductive, rigid arm and working tip electrode. The arm extends from the sleeve and includes portions laterally offset from the sleeve's longitudinal axis, providing better visualization of the working tip electrode and operation site. The working tip electrode comes in various shapes, such as a hook or flattened spatula, depending on the surgical application. A thin jacket of insulating material covers the arm from the sleeve to the base of the working tip electrode, preventing unintentional cauterization of healthy tissue. The arm's length and configuration allow for significant spacing and lateral offset of the working tip electrode from the sleeve's longitudinal axis. The instrument is designed for easy handling and use by the surgeon and is intended for single-use, disposable applications.

The invention relates to a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) apparatus with a magnet, patient receptacle, support plate, and transmit/receive coils, allowing exposures in at least two positions with predetermined adjustment parameters. The apparatus determines required adjustment parameters in a preceding adjustment process and executes exposures in a subsequent exposure process, enabling high-contrast exposures in short times, even for larger body segments. The adjustment parameters include the position of the support plate and the configuration of the transmit/receive coils, which are stored until the examination's end. The apparatus is suitable for various MRI types, such as cylindrical or horseshoe magnets. In an embodiment, the apparatus tracks contrast agent flow over larger body regions, with the support plate moving to different positions, and the transmit/receive coils being connected as in the measurement preparation. The adjustment parameters are used for immediate imaging measurements without a new adjustment, ensuring high-contrast exposures and reduced examination times.

<summary>
The invention provides a releasable album fastener consisting of a strap and two identical strap anchors, one for the front cover and one for the back cover. The strap passes through aligned holes in the covers and pages, and is secured to the anchors using a snap-lock mechanism. The strap anchors are channels with locking lips at the open side, and the strap has ribs that engage with ribs on the base of the channel to prevent longitudinal displacement. The strap anchors are attached to the covers using adhesive or double-sided tape, and the strap is inserted through the covers and pages, then snapped into the anchors. The strap can be released from either anchor to add or remove pages, and the length of the strap can be adjusted to accommodate varying album thicknesses. The strap anchors are designed to have a low profile to fit inside the covers when closed. In a modified embodiment, the ribs on the strap and anchors have a saw-tooth profile to prevent slipping, and additional ribs are added around the aperture in the channel for further security. The invention offers easier page insertion and removal, greater versatility in album size, and comparable cost to conventional screw-type fasteners.
</summary>

The invention relates to a lightweight sulky for trotting races, made of light metal and other durable materials, with a design that allows easy assembly and disassembly for storage and transportation. The sulky has a stable construction with shafts and a crossbar transferring loads directly to the wheel planes, and it can be assembled using simple hand tools and ordinary manufacturing tolerances.

The invention relates to a ventilation system for rotating water feeds, particularly in water-cooled generators with coaxial feed and discharge ducts. The system aims to automatically remove air or gas bubbles that accumulate in the rotating pipes. The invention provides a bypass with at least one inlet and one outlet, arranged between the feed duct and the discharge duct, with the inlet opening into the space around the axis of rotation. This design utilizes the pressure gradient between the inflow and outflow for automatic operation. The bypass can be arranged in or on an end face of the feed ducts, or designed as a radially arranged pipe with inlets in the space around the axis of rotation. It can also be structured as a coiled pipe. To minimize leakage and bypass flow, the bypass can include means for increasing hydrodynamic resistance. The invention offers a simple, effective solution for ventilating rotating water feeds, ensuring efficient cooling and preventing local overheating.

The invention relates to a steering column for a motor vehicle, which comprises a jacket unit supporting a steering shaft rotatably about its longitudinal axis and a retaining part, which the jacket unit is secured non displaceably up to a limit value of a force acting onto the jacket unit parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the front of the motor vehicle. If the limit value is exceeded, the jacket unit is displaceable parallel to the longitudinal axis in the direction toward the motor vehicle front. The jacket unit is connected with the retaining part, for one, across an energy absorption connection, which comprises at least one bending wire or strip that, upon a displacement of the jacket unit with respect to the retaining part parallel to the longitudinal direction toward the motor vehicle front, is deformed, and is connected, for another, across a break-away connection which, up to the limit value of the force, is closed and blocks a displacement of the jacket unit with respect to the retaining part and which is released if the limit value of the force is exceeded. The invention further relates to a method for the production of such a steering column. In the steering column of the invention an elastic prestress is exerted onto the at least one bending wire or strip. The jacket unit is thereby prestressed with respect to the retaining part in the displacement direction parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the vehicle front. This prestress acts on the break-away connection between the jacket unit and the retaining part. The force required in the event of a crash to release the break-away connection is thereby decreased since the elastic reset force of the at least one bending wire or strip is added to the force exerted, in particular through the secondary collision of the driver with the steering wheel, parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the vehicle front. The force peak during the breaking away of the jacket unit from the retaining part (=break-away peak) can thereby be decreased or entirely avoided. Nevertheless, in normal driving operation (thus when no vehicle crash occurs), an adequately stable connection is provided between the retaining part and the jacket unit, through which a shaking between the jacket unit and the retaining part and vibrations through intrinsic resonances can be avoided, and this can be achieved with a very simple implementation.

The present invention provides a method for installing a flat, uncontoured glass panel in a curved vehicle window opening. The method involves placing the flat glass panel within the curved window bay, securing it with a holding means that maintains the glass in the curved shape, and then applying a weather sealant and adhesive compound along the edges of the window panel. The adhesive is allowed to cure, permanently fixing the panel in its conforming curvature within the window opening.

The present invention provides an apparatus and method for removing a first gas from a liquid by physically displacing it with a second gas. The apparatus includes a vessel with multiple gasification chambers, each containing a gas ingesting and mixing mechanism that introduces the second gas into the liquid, creating a turbulent area that forces the first gas out of the liquid and into a vapor space above it. The first gas is then removed from the vapor space through a vent. The liquid, now containing the second gas, flows sequentially through the chambers, with each chamber further reducing the concentration of the first gas in the liquid. The number of chambers can be varied to achieve the desired level of first gas removal. The apparatus is particularly suited for use on floating offshore hydrocarbon recovery platforms due to its reduced height compared to conventional stripping towers. The method involves continuously introducing a flow of liquid containing the first gas into the inlet chamber, flowing it through the gasification chambers, and removing the treated liquid through an outlet. The rate of liquid removal can be regulated by a valve or other control mechanism. The apparatus may also include a chemical scavenging feed unit to further treat the liquid if desired.

The disclosure relates to a packaging machine with multiple work stations synchronized by a central shaft driven in alternating directions. The shaft drives tool members of various work stations, such as a forming station, sealing station, and separating station, through transfer mechanisms like toggle levers or cam mechanisms. The packaging machine can have a compact design with work stations arranged on different vertical levels. The shaft is supported by a frame to minimize vibrations, and tool members can be displaced in the production direction without acting on the shaft or transfer mechanism. In one embodiment, the packaging machine is a deep-drawing machine with two sealing stations and two separating stations, all driven by the central shaft.

The invention provides a disposable finishing article, such as a grinding wheel, with a drive member that securely holds the article during operation and is light in weight, vibration-free, and less expensive than prior art throw-away articles. The drive member includes a backing flange with gripping means and a retaining nut that secures the backing flange to the finishing article without the use of adhesives. A pressure cap is held in place by the gripping means and extends to engage the power tool spindle seat, placing the finishing article in compression during use. The more force applied to the finishing article during use, the greater the operational compression becomes, ensuring that the finishing article cannot rotate relative to the drive member and cannot disengage from the spindle. The drive member assembly requires no adhesive for construction, is simple and easy to assemble, and accommodates all currently known sizes of standard diameter depressed center grinding wheels. The invention meets all safety standards currently known and in existence.

The invention relates to a hydraulic unit for a vehicle brake system, comprising a housing block with at least one pump having a piston, an electric motor for driving the piston via a cam element, and a cam element chamber for receiving the cam element. The unit is designed to be immersion-proof, with a conduit extending downward from the cam element chamber to the atmosphere through the housing block, and a check valve opening toward the atmosphere built into the conduit. The unit also comprises at least one reservoir for temporarily receiving pressure fluid, with a cylindrical hollow chamber closed off from the ambient atmosphere, a piston displaceable in the chamber dividing it into a variable storage chamber and a spring chamber, and a spring acting on the piston. The spring chamber is connected to the cam element chamber via a conduit, allowing pressure fluid entrained by the piston to be diverted into the spring chamber. The conduit comprises first conduit portions extending downward from the cam element chamber and discharging into the spring chamber, and second conduit portions connecting the cam element chamber to the interior of the motor. The first and second conduit portions are utilized in two ways, providing a cost savings compared with two separately embodied conduits. The motor is secured to the housing block by screws, with a sealing element extending around the threaded holes to prevent pressure fluid from reaching the interior of the motor. The sealing element is made of a sealing material poured or sprayed onto the securing face of the housing block, or stamped out from a plate. The cable sheath of a cable supplying current to the motor acts as a pressure equalization conduit between the ambient atmosphere and the interior of the motor and the housing, preventing the invasion of water to the hydraulic unit while providing pressure equalization.

The invention relates to a power and free conveyor system where carriers are moved along predetermined paths by engagement with conveyors. The carriers have three dogs: a first dog for normal operation, a second dog for short transfers, and a third dog for long transfers. These dogs are normally held out of operative position by the track but can be moved to operative position by cut-outs in the track. The second and third dogs have counterweights and cam projections that engage portions of the track to hold them out of operative position. The cam projection on the second dog extends oppositely to the cam projection on the third dog. The system allows for selective transfer of the carrier over short and long distances as desired.

The invention relates to a grounding product for railroad car center plate assembly bowl liners made of all polymeric material, specifically ultra high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMW-PE) mixed with 2% carbon black to provide electrical conductivity while maintaining self-lubricating properties. The liner is designed to replace conventional manganese steel liners and eliminate the need for separate grounding apparatus. It provides two slip surfaces to ensure adequate truck swiveling action and resists wear, compaction, and deterioration. The liner meets electrical conductivity standards of 1×10^5 ohms (100 Kohms) and has a coefficient of friction similar to that of an all UHMW-PE liner.

<summary>
The invention is a gate valve for controlling bulk dispensing of viscous substances from bags or pouches, designed for one-handed operation. The valve consists of a tubular sleeve that inserts into the bag's spout, with a dispensing passage and a curved guide plate at the outlet end. A reciprocable gate, curved complementally to the guide, slides on the guide plate to control flow. The gate has lugs for finger operation, allowing it to be opened and closed with one hand. The valve can be tilted for complete discharge of the bag's contents and can be disassembled for cleaning. The valve is designed to be used with a dispenser that holds the bag in an inclined position. The gate valve member can be moved between opened and closed positions using the fingers of one hand, with the index finger and middle finger engaging the lugs of the guide member and the thumb engaging the lug of the gate valve member. The valve provides complete unobstruction of the passage when opened and an effective seal when closed. The valve can be readily disassembled and reassembled for cleaning.
</summary>

The invention provides a vehicular rearview mirror system that can adapt to different protocols of an output from a vehicle control, such as a reverse-gear indication. The system uses a microcontroller to monitor the output and determine its protocol through a software-based process. The microcontroller maintains two parameters, reverse-inhibit-running average and reverse-inhibit-ignition-cycle average, which are compared with fixed or variable limits to determine the protocol. The system can be used with various types of vehicles with minimal modifications, reducing the need for different hardware configurations.

<summary>
The invention relates to an anti-lock braking system for motorcycles with an anti-dive device for a damped telescopic front suspension. The anti-dive device is responsive to the brake force applied to the front wheel. The cooperation may be achieved by tapping hydraulic pressure downstream of the anti-lock control unit or by sensing and applying the actual reaction to braking force of the front wheel. The anti-lock braking system includes an anti-lock control unit, a front master cylinder, front wheel brakes, a rear master cylinder, rear wheel brakes, an anti-dive unit, and a front fork. The anti-lock control unit is interposed in the brake line between the front master cylinder and the front wheel brakes and is adapted to sense the nearly-locked condition of the front wheel and shut off the hydraulic pressure to the brake. The anti-dive unit is provided on the front fork and is adapted to control the contracting action of the telescopic front fork in accordance with an operation of the front wheel brake. The anti-dive unit includes a housing, a valve seat, a valve body, a valve spring, a piston, and a pressure receiving chamber. The housing has an upper port communicated with the lower hydraulic chamber, a lower port communicated with the hydraulic relay chamber, and a valve chamber communicating these ports with each other. The valve seat is positioned between the ports and held on a shoulder portion of the valve chamber by a retainer spring. The valve body is held in the valve chamber so as to open and close the same in cooperation with the valve seat. The valve spring urges the valve body in the valve-open direction. The piston is formed integrally with the valve body and extends to the outside of the valve chamber. The pressure receiving chamber is defined within the housing and is communicated with the output port of the front master cylinder via a pipe. The anti-dive unit is adapted to suitably restrict the contracting action of the front fork when a downward load is applied from the chassis to the front fork to cause the front fork to start contracting, thereby minimizing the variations in the angular deceleration of the front wheel.
</summary>

The invention provides an improved partition system for refrigerated trailers, allowing independent movement of multiple panels to create separate cargo areas at different temperatures. The panels can be slidably attached to ceiling-mounted rails and raised like garage doors when not in use. The system enables efficient multi-temperature transport by minimizing the volume of air that needs to be temperature controlled.

The invention describes a sanitizable rotary valve for use in liquid chromatography, particularly for pharmaceutical manufacturing. The valve has a rotor with a diaphragm seal that can be partially separated from the stator for cleaning, and a barrier fluid flow path to prevent contamination. The valve is designed to be used in a simulated moving bed (SMB) system, which allows for continuous counter-current separation of biomolecules.

The present invention relates to an improved valve-tray assembly for gas-liquid contacting trays in process columns, featuring directional thrust valves that enhance vapor-liquid interaction and tray efficiency. The valves are mounted on the tray with first and second support legs, where the first leg is wider and intercepts liquid flow, directing it around the valve. The valve's orientation and shape, along with its biased rear end, facilitate initial vapor flow and reduce back-trapping of liquid into the aperture.

The invention is a fluid pressure regulator assembly that generates power while regulating fluid pressure. It comprises a pressurized fluid source, a high-pressure line, a vane motor, a transfer line, a fluid regulator, and an output line. The vane motor converts pressurized fluid into mechanical power, reducing the pressure of the fluid before it reaches the regulator. This allows for the use of a smaller or less expensive regulator. The assembly can be used in various applications, such as gas grills, scuba diving equipment, and vehicles powered by pressurized flammable fluids. The vane motor can be coupled to a generator to produce electricity, or it can be used to generate mechanical work directly. The assembly can also include multiple vane motors, with some used to produce electricity and others used to produce mechanical work.

The invention relates to a pallet system designed to facilitate loading and unloading of trays and limit the shifting of loaded items. The system consists of a pallet with raised, parallel guide rails that allow trays with side supports to be slid onto the pallet, restricting both lateral and longitudinal movement. Vertically positioned end plates at both edges of the pallet further secure the load. The pallet system is suitable for automated loading and unloading and provides enhanced stability when loaded and wrapped.

<summary>
The electrical driven flying saucer based on magnetic suspension comprises a saucer shell, a saucer cabin, a rotary-wing system, and a control system. The rotary-wing system is a magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing system consisting of magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels, an electromotive ring, a magnetic suspension shaft, and a magnetic suspension guide rail. The electromotive ring, magnetic suspension shaft, and magnetic suspension guide rail are fixed to the saucer shell, while the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels are suspended in the space restricted by these components and go around the magnetic suspension shaft under an electromagnetic thrust. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels comprise blades, a magnetic suspension inner ring, and a magnetic suspension outer ring, forming an impeller. The magnetic suspension guide rail includes an inner ring upper guideway, an inner ring lower guideway, an outer ring upper guideway, and an outer ring lower guideway. The magnetic suspension inner ring of the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels surrounds the magnetic suspension shaft and is disposed between the inner ring upper guideway and the inner ring lower guideway, while the magnetic suspension outer ring is embedded in the electromotive ring and disposed between the outer ring upper guideway and the outer ring lower guideway. The magnetic suspension inner ring and the magnetic suspension shaft form a repulsive or attractive magnetic suspension radial bearing, and the magnetic suspension inner ring and the magnetic suspension inner ring guide rail, as well as the magnetic suspension outer ring and the magnetic suspension outer ring guide rail, form repulsive or attractive magnetic suspension axial bearings. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels, electromotive ring, and magnetic suspension shaft constitute a magnetic suspension electric engine, with the electromotive ring acting as a stator, the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels as a rotor, and the magnetic suspension shaft as a spindle. The electric engine adopts a permanent magnet synchronous motor, with pairs of permanent magnets embedded in the magnetic suspension outer ring to form an exciter field, and 3-phase symmetric stator windings distributed inside stator grooves to generate a rotating magnetic field that pushes the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels to rotate. Two sets of independent magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing systems can be superposed and mounted coaxially inside the saucer shell in the axial or radial direction to form coaxial axial or radial dual magnetic suspension electromotive rotary wings. The upper and lower or inner and outer rotary-wing systems rotate in reverse directions, adopt reverse inclination directions of blades, and can overcome or offset the reactive

The invention relates to streptavidin muteins with increased binding affinity for peptide ligands, a process for their production, and their use in isolation, purification, and detection of proteins. The streptavidin muteins are characterized by at least one mutation in the region of amino acids 44 to 53, resulting in a higher binding affinity for peptide ligands compared to wild-type streptavidin. The peptide ligands have the amino acid sequence Trp-Xaa-His-Pro-Gln-Phe-Xaa-Xaa, where Xaa can be any amino acid, and Y and Z are either both Gly or Y is Glu and Z is Arg or Lys. The streptavidin muteins can be used in affinity chromatography for the purification of proteins fused with the peptide ligand, and in detection methods such as ELISA or Western blot. The invention also relates to a reagent kit containing the streptavidin mutein and optionally standard buffer and auxiliary substances and additives.

The invention provides methods for synthesizing substituted guanidines using nickel catalysts, particularly nickel in the zero oxidation state derived from alloys like nickel-boride or nickel-phosphide, or supported on materials like kieselguhr or silica/alumina. These methods involve reacting guanylating agents such as thioureas or isothioureas with amines or pyrrolidines in the presence of the nickel catalyst, typically at room temperature and in a suitable solvent, to yield the desired guanidine products in high yields.

The invention provides an apparatus and method for continuously coloring aluminum strips or wires by first anodizing them in a sulfuric acid bath to form an oxide film, then electrolytically coloring the film in a bath containing at least one of a nickel salt, cobalt salt, copper salt, tin salt, or selenious acid. The apparatus includes a means for supplying the aluminum, an anodic oxidation bath with a cathode, an electrolytic coloring bath with an anode, an electric circuit connecting the cathode and anode to a power source, and a means for passing the aluminum through the baths. The oxide film thickness should be at least 4 microns for effective coloring. The electrolytic coloring bath composition and conditions can be varied to achieve different colors. The aluminum strip or wire acts as an anode in the anodic oxidation bath and a cathode in the electrolytic coloring bath without being directly connected to the power source.

The invention provides a process of producing transgenic plants or plant cells transformed on a chromosome with a DNA sequence of interest and capable of expressing a function of interest from said DNA sequence of interest, said process comprising providing plant cells or plants with at least two different vectors adapted to recombine with each other by site-specific recombination in said plant cells for producing a non-replicating recombination product containing said DNA sequence of interest, and selecting plants or plant cells expressing said function of interest. The invention also provides transgenic plants or parts thereof produced by this process, and libraries of plants, plant cells, or plant seeds obtained or obtainable according to this process.

The present invention is a swash plate type compressor with an improved swash plate coating.
