These waveguide hologram illuminators offer advantages such as compact size, high diffraction efficiency, and minimal stray light, but also present challenges like alignment sensitivity, illumination depletion, and two-sided diffraction that can be addressed through various techniques.

The invention provides a method and apparatus for non-destructive testing of dynamoelectric machine rotors, specifically squirrel cage rotors for induction motors. The test apparatus comprises a test head that accepts and rotates the rotor, exciting means to magnetize the rotor, voltage sensing means to generate a voltage signal responsive to the rotor's magnetic flux variations, current sensing means to sense the alternating current used for magnetization, and processing means to determine the rotor's resistance and reactance. The test head also includes skew sensing means to sense the effective electrical skew of the rotor. The processing means calculates the resistance, reactance, and effective skew using the voltage, current, and skew signals. The apparatus automatically performs the test sequence, acquires data, processes it, and provides pass/fail determinations. The data acquisition and processing system includes a data processor and a control processor for efficient data handling. The control processor also manages the test sequence, including rotor retraction and rotation. The apparatus can test multiple rotors simultaneously using a dual fixture system, improving efficiency. The test results, including calculated values and statistical data, are displayed on a terminal and can be printed. The apparatus stores statistical data on a Winchester disk for analysis over multiple tests.

The text describes a process for publishing videogames configured to execute on a mobile device. The process involves receiving a package from a networked computer system, identifying an executable in the package, verifying managed metadata associated with the executable, and signing the package with a private key. The verification of the managed metadata includes inspecting it at runtime to determine that the executable includes type safe code. The process also involves transmitting the signed package to a community feedback server, where it can be reviewed by peer reviewers. The peer reviewers can add to the package by downloading the source code of the executable and using a software development kit to add to the executable. The process concludes by publishing the package to an electronic market place, where it can be purchased by members of the public.

The invention relates to an improved identification card with an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip, protected by being sandwiched between two flexible, shock-absorbing layers made of silica-filled polyolefin. These layers are then encased between two rigid outer layers, providing structural support and protection. The card is produced by pre-shrinking a core layer, printing indicia and an alkyd resin spid on one side, and attaching an antenna and IC chip to the spid. A bottom sheet is attached to the core layer using an adhesive layer, sandwiching the electronic components. Two polymer layers are then attached to the core layer and bottom sheet, providing mechanical strength and protection. The card can be personalized using dye diffusion thermal transfer or inkjet printing.

The invention provides a method for implementing a queue, specifically a FIFO-type queue, in a memory, particularly a functional memory where updates are made by copying the path from the root to the point of updating. The queue is implemented using a tree-shaped data structure where nodes have a maximum size, and additions are made to the first non-full node on the first edge of the tree, while deletions are made from a leaf node on the opposite edge. The tree is maintained such that leaf nodes remain at the same hierarchy level, and new nodes are created if necessary to keep the balance condition. A preferred embodiment includes a separate header node with three elements pointing to the end, middle (tree), and beginning of the queue. Additions are made to the end node first, and only then to the tree, while deletions are made from the tree first, and then from the beginning node. Another preferred embodiment uses an inversion bit in the header node to indicate the direction of the queue, allowing for constant time and space inversion. The queue can also be used as a double-ended queue (deque) with additions and deletions from both ends. The memory arrangement includes an actual memory, intermediate registers for the end and beginning nodes, a flag register for the inversion bit, and control logic for maintaining the queue.

The invention provides methods to manufacture embedded Electrically Programmable Read-Only Memory (EPROM) devices using existing Integrated Circuit (IC) technologies, specifically DRAM and logic technologies. The EPROM devices are built using DRAM storage capacitors as coupling capacitors and common transistors that experience property changes under electrical stress. These EPROM devices have advantages such as lower operation voltages, smaller area, and the ability to be reprogrammed, making them suitable for embedded applications like DRAM redundancy circuits and programmable logic circuits. The EPROM devices can be manufactured without adding cost to existing DRAM or logic manufacturing procedures, and they do not require high voltages for operation.

The invention provides a method for determining optimal feedback gain values in a feedback control system. The method involves provisionally setting a feedback gain value, executing feedback control using this value, detecting an error between a desired value and the actual value of the controlled variable, calculating an evaluation value based on the detected error, and repeating these steps with different gain values. The optimal gain value is then calculated based on the relationship between the gain values and their corresponding evaluation values. In the case of determining the proportional gain, the evaluation value is the ratio of the length of the error curve to the length of the time axis, and the optimal gain value is the one that minimizes this ratio. For the integral gain, the evaluation value is the integral of the error, and the optimal gain value is the one that minimizes this integral. For the differential gain, the evaluation value is the integral of the absolute value of the error, and the optimal gain value is the one that minimizes this integral. The method can be applied to various feedback control systems, including those used in automatic guidance vehicles.

The invention provides a zoom lens with a large relative aperture, high zoom ratio, and standard image angle at the wide angle end, while minimizing the size and total length of the lens system. The lens comprises, from front to rear, a first lens unit of positive power for focusing, a second lens unit of negative power for varying magnification, a third lens unit of negative power for compensating image shift, a fourth lens unit with a positive lens for making the diverging light beam from the third lens unit almost parallel, and a fifth lens unit with an image forming function and lenses of positive, negative, positive, negative, positive, and positive powers in this order. The lens satisfies certain conditions related to the focal lengths, radii of curvature, Abbe numbers, and refractive powers of the lenses to achieve good optical performance throughout the entire zooming range.

The invention provides a method and device for detecting elementary particles, such as protons, ions, electrons, neutrons, photons, etc., in a detector. The method involves generating a charge pulse in the detector when a particle passes through it, converting the charge pulse into an electric signal, and amplifying and indicating or recording the signal. The device includes a detector for generating a charge pulse, an amplification device for converting the charge pulse into an electric signal and amplifying it, and optionally a display and/or recording device. The method and device enable both the detection of individual particles and the integration of a plurality of signals, without knowing in advance the count or signal rates to be expected. The device includes a first, fast amplifier for amplifying individual signals and a second, slow amplifier for integrating signals. The tapping of the charge pulses or signals is provided on the low-voltage side of the detector, in particular with the arrangement of a support capacitor. The method and device can be used for detecting particles in particle accelerators, reactor installations, diagnostic devices such as X-ray devices, CT devices, or the like.

The invention relates to an automatic spin checking apparatus for driven disc assemblies used in friction clutches. The apparatus comprises a stationary ring and a movable ring that frictionally engage the driven disc assembly when moved together. A torque motor rotates the driven disc assembly, and a position sensor measures the distance between the rings. The movable ring is gradually moved away from the stationary ring, reducing the frictional force on the driven disc assembly. When the driven disc assembly rotates, the distance between the rings is measured again. The difference between these distances indicates the warpage of the driven disc assembly, which is compared to a standard value to determine if it's within acceptable tolerances. The apparatus operates automatically and provides external indications to the operator of the test results.

The present invention relates to methods and software for estimating the age of a person from an image using a contourlet appearance model (CAM) algorithm and aging functions. The method involves extracting facial features from an image using a feature extractor, mapping the features to an age group using a feature-space-to-age-space mapping unit, and applying an aging function to generate an estimated age. The invention also includes a training method for generating aging functions and an age classifier using a database of landmarked face images. The training method involves extracting feature vectors from the images using a CAM algorithm, constructing aging functions using support vector regression, and building an age classifier using support vector machines. The invention also includes a face age-estimation system that can implement the methods and a machine-readable storage medium containing machine-executable instructions for performing the methods.

The invention describes a matrix display device that merges two images with different definitions. The device uses a mosaic of identical arrangements of pixels, where some pixels are dedicated to the first image and others to the second image. The controller of the display device applies light intensity signals to the pixels based on the corresponding pixels of the first and second images. The merged image is displayed on the matrix display device, with the two images being redimensioned by scaling means if necessary. The controller can also apply an attenuation function to the light intensity signals of the first image pixels if the corresponding pixels of the second image have a quantified light intensity signal value greater than a predetermined threshold value.

The invention relates to a mobile identification transmitter for activating a motor vehicle's security system, with a housing containing electronics and communication means for interacting with the vehicle's communication means. The transmitter also includes a payment element removably fastened in a housing receptacle, with a separate closure to protect and seal the receptacle when the payment element is removed, placing the transmitter in a secure state. In the normal state, the payment element can communicate with a payment system, while in the secure state, the payment element is removed, and the closure protects the receptacle.

The disclosed system and methods address the issue of inconsistent image quality in an imaging device after a period of inactivity by intelligently controlling the tribo charge of toner. The system determines periods of inactivity, predicts the next user usage, and charges the toner to a predetermined level based on the calculated decay of the tribo charge during the inactivity period. The toner charging process may involve measuring the toner charge level when the machine is recovered from inactivity and charging the toner to a predetermined level based on the difference between the measured charge and the predetermined level. The system may also include a self-learning algorithm to determine user usage patterns and predict future usage.

The invention provides a rotary magnetic head type apparatus capable of controlling bias currents for plural magneto resistive (MR) heads mounted on a rotary drum with high precision using a single control signal transmitted from a stationary drum side. The apparatus comprises a control signal generator for generating control signals for controlling the operating amperages of MR heads, a decoder circuit for discriminating data of the control signals, and a current supply circuit for supplying operating currents to the MR heads in response to the output signals of the decoder circuit. The control signals are transmitted over a single channel of a rotary transformer and set the operating currents of the MR heads. The apparatus also includes regenerative integrated circuits comprising a current supply circuit and a regenerative amplifier, which are controlled with digital data on three lines including Data, Clock and Chip Select (CS) lines. The control signal generator generates control signals for controlling the regenerative integrated circuits, and the decoder circuit discriminates data of the control signals and supplies the three-line signals for controlling the regenerative integrated circuits. The apparatus is configured to give priority to head switching signal data and MR bias current data in the transmission of digital data at the time of head switching to prevent loss or wrong setting of data at the time of head switching.

The invention improves the locating and tracing of one concealed object, such as a buried pipe or cable, in the presence of an adjacent object. It uses a transmitter with two antennae to induce distinguishable alternating currents in the objects and a receiver that senses the magnetic fields associated with these currents and produces an output signal dependent on both fields. The transmitter's antennae are spaced a few feet apart and driven by RF signals with distinguishable characteristics, such as different carrier frequencies or modulation frequencies. The receiver is sensitive to both magnetic fields and produces an output signal only when both fields are sensed. The invention is particularly useful when the horizontal separation between the objects is less than 1.5 times their depth. The transmitter's position can be optimized to enhance the inducement of currents in the respective objects and improve the receiver's performance. The receiver's output signal characteristic may have two distinct nulls over the respective objects, making it easier to locate and trace one of the objects. The invention can be implemented using different techniques to distinguish the currents in the respective objects and produce an output signal dependent on the presence of both currents. The receiver's threshold sensitivity can be adjusted to optimize its performance.

The invention provides a portable, modular device that interfaces a two-way speaker phone with a telephone network, enabling hands-free automatic answering and communication. The device includes a selector switch for choosing between regular and automatic operation, a coupler for connecting incoming calls to the speaker phone, a timer for limiting call duration, and an extend switch for overriding the timer. The device can be easily connected to an existing telephone system through a wall jack, making it versatile and convenient for various applications.

The present invention is a trunk and branch ring network for optical fiber communications that reduces or eliminates the need for undersea optical repeaters by using remotely pumped optical amplifiers powered over the same branch cables that distribute communications signals. The network consists of an optical fiber cable trunk configured in a ring topology with one or more telecommunications hubs and branching units serially interconnected along the trunk. The hubs are access points for major switching offices to route communications onto or from the cable trunk, while the branching units allow for convenient add/drop points for telecommunications traffic from the cable trunk. A branch fiber optic cable connected to each branching unit accesses one or more signal wavelengths transported along the cable trunk and also unidirectionally transmits optical energy at a wavelength other than that of the signal wavelength to power an optical amplifier located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit. Similarly, a light emitting power source coupled to the optical fiber cable trunk at the hub location transmits optical energy at a wavelength other than the signal wavelength to power an optical amplifier located remotely from the hub. This arrangement provides several advantages, including maintaining full connectivity along the trunk and to all cable stations via their respective branch fiber optic cables in the event of a single trunk cut, isolating only the associated cable station in the event of a branch cut, respecting sovereignty concerns, allowing for reconfigurable wavelength add/drop branching units, and reducing capital, operating, and maintenance costs by eliminating the need for repeaters.

The invention is a two-part cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices, consisting of an attachment member and a cover plate member. The attachment member is symmetrical and can be mounted to a wiring device using available fasteners, while the cover plate member has no visible fasteners and is latched onto the attachment member using latching pawls and saw-tooth shaped racks. The cover plate member can be easily removed using a small tool inserted into a slot in its bottom end wall. The device can accommodate variations in wall flatness or evenness due to the independent operation of the pawls and racks. It is suitable for use with single or multiple wiring devices and can be adapted to fit various combinations of wiring devices.

The invention is a collapsible light-shielding device for screens, such as television sets and monitors, consisting of concentrically nested annular strips that slide over one another between a pushed-in and pushed-out position. The strips have decreasing wall thickness in the axial direction, allowing for various angular positions relative to the screen. Hook elements or locking elements ensure reliable folding-in and folding-out, and an adapter member provides a flat attachment face for the light-shielding device. The strips can be solid or produced by bending plate material, and the invention aims to provide a device that is inexpensive to produce, operates reliably, and can easily be fitted to a monitor.

<summary>
The invention provides a solution to automatically inform a speaker to decrease their speaking rate when it exceeds a listener's comprehension threshold. This is achieved by determining the speaking rate of the speaker and comparing it to a speaking rate threshold, which is based on the listener's estimated or known listening rate. The listener's proficiency with the language being spoken is also considered in setting the threshold. The speaker is notified through a sensory mechanism, such as a vibration, beep, or display message, on a wearable computing device. The device can also suggest switching to an alternative language that both the speaker and listener are proficient in. The speaking rate threshold and clarity value can be adjusted based on the speaker's clarity of speech and the quality of the voice network connection. The invention can be implemented as a program for controlling computing equipment or as a method performed by a service agent or machine manipulated by a service agent in response to a service request.
</summary>

<summary>
The invention relates to a device for optical recording of rapid processes using a TV camera, with means to deviate and suppress the beam for scanning lines on a picture plane. The device includes a cyclic line counter that supplies an end-of-count pulse after p line pulses, where N/p is an integer greater than 1, triggering beam suppression and vertical deviation control. A sawtooth generator synchronized with the counter controls vertical beam deviation. A delay device controls the sawtooth generator and beam suppression circuit with a selectable delay time. The line counter is preferably programmable. The device increases the picture sequence frequency by scanning fewer lines per picture, with the resolution in the line direction remaining high. The video signals can be digitized and stored for analysis, with jumped-over lines completed by repetition or interpolation. The counter's counting capacity can be adjusted for optimal time and spatial resolution. The scanning scheme can be moved from one cycle to the next, filling interspaces between lines. The device is suitable for recording IR, UV, or X-ray pictures.</summary>

The present invention provides a method for integrating voice calls with multimedia sessions in a packet switched network, creating a blended call. A multimedia server with blender software manages the blended call, handling voice components through a telephony server and multimedia components directly. Incoming calls are routed to the blender, which initiates parallel voice and multimedia components, with the blender controlling the signaling paths. Outgoing calls from blended-capable users are also routed to the blender, which initiates the parallel components. The blender prevents infinite loops by including a loopback signal or indication when passing voice components back to the telephony server. The multimedia server maintains control over the signaling paths, allowing it to manage the bearer paths for both voice and multimedia components.

The present invention provides a content synchronization framework that allows connected devices to synchronize with a central reference point server, which constructs responses in a semantic compatible with the connected device and user, prioritizes download order of files, and downloads files to the connected device in the download order. The framework also confirms complete download of the files and rejects incompletely downloaded bundles.

The present invention provides a system and method for facilitating communication between a finder of an object and an owner of the object, allowing the owner to register an association between the object's unique ID and owner contact information, and allowing the finder to communicate with the owner via a virtual locale associated with the ID.

The invention describes a foil electron multiplier that uses a series of thin foils in an evacuated enclosure to multiply electrons in transmission stages. The multiplier comprises a series of thin foils held by foil holders in an evacuated enclosure, forming discrete multiplication stages. A voltage is applied to each foil to accelerate electrons emitted from the back of one foil to an energy level that effectively transmits the electrons through the next foil in the series, as well as generating secondary electrons that add on to the transmitted electrons and continue on to the next foil in the series. The foil electron multiplier can be used for amplification of an incident electron flux or for detection of particles, such as photons, ions, electrons, and the like, in photomultiplier tubes and particle detectors, such as channel electron multipliers and microchannel plates.

The 3-D Phenomenoscope is a device that allows viewers to experience 3-dimensional effects in ordinary 2-dimensional motion pictures. It works by detecting lateral motion in the motion picture and synchronizing the darkness of the viewer's left and right lenses accordingly. The device consists of a digital sensor that captures images of the motion picture, a processor that analyzes the images to detect motion and determine its direction, and a controller that adjusts the darkness of the lenses based on the processor's analysis. The preferred embodiment of the device uses an intensity edge map algorithm to detect motion, and the processor can store and analyze multiple frames of the motion picture to improve the accuracy of its analysis. The device can be used with any type of motion picture media, including film, digital film, VCR tape, DVD, and PC computer screens, and it does not require any special equipment or alterations to the motion picture. The 3-D Phenomenoscope is designed to be lightweight and comfortable for the viewer, and it runs on a small battery for several weeks at a time.

<summary>
The invention describes a method and apparatus for singulating semiconductor wafers using pressure instead of a wafer saw. The process involves forming trenches along scribe lines on the wafer, applying a protective layer, optionally back-grinding the wafer, and then applying mechanical pressure to cause a clean break along the trenches, singulating the individual die. A ring may be used to support the wafer during singulation. The pressure can be applied in the X and Y directions or in a circular motion. The trenches can be formed by etching or partial sawing, and can be on the active or non-active surface of the wafer.
</summary>

<summary>
The present invention provides a field emission display (FED) device with a protection structure to prevent burnout damage to field emission elements caused by electrical current surges induced by ionized gases. The protection structure includes one or more reduction plates or electrodes, typically on the cathode, which alter the discharge path of ionized gases away from the cathode. A bias voltage source applies a negative voltage to the reduction plates, attracting positive nitrogen and oxygen ions and preventing them from contacting the cathode and inducing current surges. In one embodiment, multiple elongated reduction plates run parallel and adjacent to rows of field emission elements. In another embodiment, reduction plates are arranged in a meshwork- or net-shaped configuration among the field emission elements. The reduction plates can be fabricated on the cathode at the same time as the cathode strips using photolithography and etching techniques. The FED device includes a cathode plate with cathode strips, anodes, and an operating voltage source. The protection structure prevents surges in electrical current from damaging field emission elements, substantially prolonging the lifetime of the device.
</summary>

The invention describes an image sensor with multiple imaging planes, including a top surface and two edge surfaces. The sensor is made of a P-type semiconductor substrate with a highly doped bottom layer and a more lightly doped upper layer. Image sensor elements are arranged in columns, with one column functioning with the top imaging plane and two columns functioning with the edge imaging planes. Each image sensor element includes an image sensing region and a buried-channel CCD for charge collection and transfer. The sensor's design guides charge carriers generated by light impinging on the edge surfaces towards the CCDs, enabling imaging through the edges. This allows the sensor to be used in various applications, such as simultaneous imaging of multiple planes or color scanning in a single pass.

The invention provides methods for transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device in a home network, minimizing total power consumption and ensuring optimal network administration. The master device sends data enabling network administrative functions to a slave device, which then becomes the new master device, while the original master device enters a power management state. The slave device accepts the transfer request and becomes the new master device, performing network administrative functions in addition to its nominal device functions.

<summary>
The invention relates to an antenna array for measuring the direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation, particularly at low elevation angles. The array comprises at least four antennae spaced to form at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane, each triplet characterized by its element spacing and height above the ground. The array operates by radio interferometric techniques, using a common coherent carrier for transmissions from each element of a triplet. The array provides unambiguous angle measurement through signal processing circuits in the antenna receivers or by coding transmissions from each antenna in a transmit mode. The array can operate in both receive and transmit modes, with a common coherent carrier required for interferometric performance but not for coherence between triplets. The array is designed to provide unambiguous angle measurements up to a certain degree, with measurement accuracy and resolution of a certain order, using the smallest number of antenna elements possible. The array can be used in various applications, such as monitoring the height of aircraft approaching to land or providing coding of angles in space. The array can be optimized for different elevation angles by adjusting the spacing and height of the antenna elements in each triplet.
</summary>

The invention relates to high intensity, thermal, efficient incandescent lamps, subminiature lamps, lamp assemblies, and a lamp system and method of making an efficient high intensity bulb and sleeve system having a liquid tight seal. The subminiature lamp assembly utilizes a high temperature polymer which directly surrounds and is in compression contact with the glass envelope, providing extended axial length sealing, heat resistance, ease of handling, and increased resistance to invasion and chemical attack. The polymeric material may derive support from a metal base and can be manually handled and used to manipulate the subminiature lamp. A fluoroelastomer is a preferable type of elastomer which has the chemically resistive properties and ability to withstand high temperature which can be advantageously employed. The elastomer used for the seal supported lamp assembly provides (1) extended axial length sealing, (2) heat resistance, (3) ease of handling, and (4) increased resistance to invasion and chemical attack. The seal supported subminiature lamp assembly can be mounted within a socket, with the axial bottom face of the polymeric seal support pressing against the upper radial surface of the socket to provide additional sealing and supply additional friction to help keep the seal supported subminiature lamp assembly from turning out of its threaded socket.

The present invention relates to a method for configuring a generalized decision feedback equalizer (GDFE) based precoder in a base station of a multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU-MIMO) wireless system having k user terminals (UTs), each user terminal having associated therewith a feedforward filter. The method comprises computing a filter matrix C using one of a plurality of alternative formulas of the invention as described below; and, based on the computation of the filter matrix C, computing a transmit filter matrix B for a transmit filter used to process a symbol vector obtained after a decision feedback equalizing stage of the GDFE precoder, computing the feedforward filter matrix F, and computing the interference pre-cancellation matrix G. Another aspect of the invention is directed to a GDFE based precoder in a base station of a MU-MIMO wireless system having k user terminals, each user terminal having associated therewith a feedforward filter. The GDFE precoder comprises a feedforward path; a feedback path; and an interference pre-cancellation block denoted by I-G disposed in the feedback path, I being an identity matrix, G being an interference pre-cancellation matrix. A feedforward filter matrix F is related to the interference pre-cancellation matrix by a novel expression as described below. Yet another aspect of the invention is directed to a GDFE based precoder in a base station of a MU-MIMO wireless system having k user terminals, each user terminal having associated therewith a feedforward filter. The GDFE precoder comprises a feedforward path; a feedback path; and an interference pre-cancellation block denoted by I-G disposed in the feedback path, I being an identity matrix, G being an interference pre-cancellation matrix. The interference pre-cancellation matrix G in the interference pre-cancellation block is determined by computing a filter matrix C using one of a plurality of alternative formulas of the invention as described below; and, based on the computation of the filter matrix C, computing a transmit filter matrix B for a transmit filter used to process a symbol vector obtained after a decision feedback equalizing stage of the GDFE precoder, computing the feedforward filter matrix F, and computing the interference pre-cancellation matrix G.

The invention provides a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, where an sidewall of the housing extends outwards to enlarge the intake airflow area without modifying the assembling conditions with other elements, enhancing heat-dissipating efficiency. The outward extension of the housing allows for an increased dimension of the impeller's blades, further boosting airflow rate and heat-dissipating performance. The housing's passage reduces gradually and evenly in cross-sectional area, effectively concentrating air streams to the center of a heat sink for enhanced heat dissipation. The housing can be used with an axial fan and a heat sink, dissipating heat from electrical elements in a system casing. The housing's outer frame maintains its rectangular shape and screw hole positions, ensuring unchanged assembling conditions with other elements. The housing's sidewall can extend radially outwards in a symmetrical manner, forming an inclined portion or beveled edge for enlarged intake airflow area and reduced noise. The housing's sidewall can also extend outwards in a frustum-conical or frustum-elliptically conical manner, with partial cut-offs forming notches for enlarged lateral side intake airflow area. The heat-dissipating device can be assembled with a heat sink, dissipating heat from a central processing unit (CPU) and guiding air streams towards the CPU's central portion for enhanced heat dissipation.

The electroluminescent display panel of the present invention comprises a first luminescent layer emitting green light and a second luminescent layer emitting orange light, partially overlapping the first layer. The panel displays green light at low voltage and lemon light at high voltage, suitable for day and night use in an automobile instrument panel. The panel can also include a color filter to emit red light at high voltage, displaying yellow light. The panel's color purity can be adjusted by changing the double layer proportion or the thickness of the second luminescent layer.

The invention relates to a portable communications terminal for Internet telephony, comprising audio means for reproducing and recording sound, converting means for converting sound into and from a suitable digital format, and protocol means for handling and controlling communication according to a standardized Internet/network protocol. The terminal also includes wireless communications means for near field communication with a connecting unit that establishes a connection to a network or the Internet. The wireless communications means embeds and extracts data packets in/from a wireless data format. The terminal may communicate additional information with the connecting unit, such as IP addresses or data packets, and may establish a connection to a service server via the connecting unit to pass on information concerning a desired communication receiver. The terminal may also comprise speech recognition means for analyzing and interpreting sound to identify commands.

The invention provides a method and structure for integrating high-dielectric constant oxides, such as ferroelectrics, directly onto semiconductor substrates like Si or GaAs. A buffer layer of non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide, such as BaSrTiO3, is grown directly or indirectly on the semiconductor substrate, followed by the deposition of a Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide, like PbZrTiO3. A thin Ge layer can be used as a buffer between the semiconductor and the non-Pb/Bi-containing oxide to prevent the formation of a low dielectric constant layer and enhance epitaxy. The buffer layer also acts as a chemical barrier and nucleates the desired perovskite structure. The structure can be used in various semiconductor devices, such as capacitors, MOS transistors, and non-volatile memory cells. The use of a second buffer layer and a top electrode is also disclosed.

The invention relates to a receiver input circuit with multiple amplification control loops to minimize distortions caused by strong signals. The circuit comprises a preamplifier, tunable selective network, mixer and oscillator stage, and intermediate frequency selective filter. Three control loops are employed: the first controls the preamplifier stage to prevent mixer and varactor diode overloading, the second controls the mixer stage to avoid mixer and oscillator stage overloading, and the third, with a lower response threshold and bandwidth, supports the other control circuits or reduces the signal response threshold from a certain spurious signal level on. The control signal for each loop is derived from the intermediate frequency signal and supplied to the respective part of the circuit. The control signal is processed in a control signal processing circuit and used to control a PIN diode in the input network for signal attenuation. The input network may include extended reactance networks and tunable selective circuits for higher selectivity and control range. The tunable network may be aligned iteration-free using a separate tuning voltage supply and adjustment, or a single twin diode may be used for both resonant circuits with a common tuning voltage.

<summary>
The invention provides a system for initiating a collaborative work-share environment between two or more parties to a telephone call without complex setup processes. Each party is provided with a collaboration button and an indicator on their telephone set. When the indicator is illuminated, the system can establish a work-share environment. In response to one party activating the collaboration button, the system causes network-enabled applications to run on the individual users' desktop computers, allowing the parties to share information, conduct a video conference, etc., while maintaining their initial voice connection. The telephone is used in the usual way to make regular, voice-only, telephone calls. Once a call is established, the telephones communicate with each other to determine if they each are associated with equipment that would allow richer collaboration between their respective users. If such equipment is available, the indicator on at least one of the telephones is lit, indicating that richer collaboration is possible. If the talking parties decide that they would like to share a document or set up a video conference, this may be initiated by either party pushing the collaboration button. Once the button has been pushed, one of a number of subsequent scenarios are possible, with the voice path unaffected and the talking parties able to continue their conversation uninterrupted. The system includes a call control unit with phone proxies, each associated with a telephone and maintaining the call state for the associated telephone. The phone proxies include a database containing the telephone number and IP address of the phone as well as the IP address of any PC associated with the phone. The collaboration control program runs on each PC associated with a telephone and has the capability of communicating over the LAN with the phone to control the collaborate indicator and sense actuation of the collaborate button. The collaboration control program includes a list of all collaboration application programs installed which have been registered with the collaboration control program on the PC, including information about their capabilities and communication protocols. The collaboration control program has the capability of launching a collaboration application program or, in the event that it is already running in the background, to bring the collaboration application program to the foreground. The collaboration control program also has the ability to communicate with the collaboration control programs of remote PCs via the LAN and to compare remote and local collaboration application programs and, by comparing supported protocols, determine whether the mutual collaboration application programs can inter-operate in a shared work environment. The system can be implemented in a variety of architectures, including a centralized call control unit and a peer-to-peer architecture. The invention can be implemented by remote computers connected over a network, with the

The invention relates to a method for inserting an advertising clip into a video sequence at a point called an insertion point. The method involves generating a salience map representing the salience of the video sequence before the insertion point and a salience map for each advertising clip in a set of advertising clips. A degree of similarity is then determined between the salience map of the video sequence and the salience map of each advertising clip. The advertising clip with the highest degree of similarity is selected and inserted into the video sequence at the insertion point. The insertion point is preferably a point corresponding to a shot change in the video sequence. The degree of similarity can be determined using various methods, such as calculating the correlation coefficient, the Kullback-Leibler divergence, or by comparing the maximum salience points of the salience maps. The method can also involve preselecting advertising clips based on their semantic content with respect to the video sequence.

The invention provides a semiconductor device structure and process for reducing electrical breakdown and leakage in sub-250 nanometer interconnects by recessing a mask layer below high electric field points, minimizing damage to diffusion barriers, and allowing for independent control of mask thickness to reduce overall capacitance.

The Downconverting Digitizer is a novel analog-to-digital converter that uses predictive coding principles to directly sample and downconvert a modulated intermediate frequency (IF) signal to digital in-phase (I) and quadrature (Q) baseband components. It consists of a digitally-controlled variable gain amplifier, a gain control logic element, an analog summing element, a 1-bit analog-to-digital converter (ADC) sampler, a predictive digital filter, an offset nuller element, a digital summing element, a digital-to-analog converter (DAC), and a digital quadrature mixer. The predictive loop generates a prediction of the input signal, which is subtracted from the input to generate a prediction error signal. The predictive filter is implemented using digital signal processing techniques and is designed to minimize the prediction error signal. The offset nuller dynamically estimates and removes offsets introduced by implementation imperfections. The gain control logic maintains the amplitude of the modulated carrier within the dynamic range of the predictive loop. The digital quadrature mixer downconverts the output of the predictive filter to baseband I and Q components. The overall Downconverting Digitizer has an analog section, a digital section, and a mixed-signal section, with the analog section minimized to allow maximum use of digital signal processing techniques. The invention is distinguished from prior art in four major aspects: the placement of the sampler inside the predictive loop, the operation of the predictive encoder in a subharmonic mode, the use of the digital predictive loop output to control the gain level applied to the input signal, and the incorporation of an offset nuller to eliminate biases introduced by implementation imperfections.

The invention describes a multiplex detection array that uses nanoimprint lithography to create semiconductor nanotraces on each sensor device. These nanotraces are functionalized with specific probe molecules, allowing the sensor devices to detect complementary target molecules. The array is designed to detect multiple targets simultaneously, with each sensor device responding to a specific target. The detection is based on changes in electrical current through the semiconductor nanotraces when target molecules bind to the probe molecules. The array is fabricated using standard photolithography for the base electrode structures, followed by nanoimprint lithography to pattern the semiconductor nanotraces. The probe molecules are synthesized directly on the surface of the semiconductor nanotraces using photogenerated reagent (PGR) chemistry. The multiplex detection array is packaged onto an electronics board for signal acquisition and processing.

The present invention provides a method of singulating semiconductor packages that includes plating the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe in order to prevent contamination of the lead surfaces. The method involves providing a plurality of semiconductor dies coupled to a single common leadframe, singulating the plurality of semiconductor dies, wherein the leadframe is at least partially cut between adjacent semiconductor dies, thereby forming exposed side surfaces on leads of the leadframe, and plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads with a plating material, wherein the plating material is a different material than the leads. The leads are preferably copper, and the plating material is preferably a metallic material configured not to react with oxygen, such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold. The singulation process can be performed in a single full cutting operation or in multiple partial cutting operations. In some embodiments, the semiconductor dies are attached to the bottom surface of the leadframe, and the method further comprises plating the top surface of the leadframe before or after the singulation process. In some embodiments, the leadframe has a top surface and a bottom surface opposite the top surface, and the step of singulating the plurality of semiconductor dies comprises performing a first partial cut of the leadframe, wherein the first partial cut does not extend all the way between the bottom surface and the top surface, and performing a second partial cut of the leadframe, wherein the second partial cut is performed separately from the first partial cut and completes the singulation of the semiconductor dies all the way between the bottom surface and the top surface of the leadframe, thereby forming a plurality of singulated semiconductor packages. In some embodiments, the step of plating the exposed side surfaces is performed in between the first partial cut and the second partial cut. In some embodiments, the first partial cut is performed using a blade having a first thickness and the second partial cut is performed using a blade having a second thickness, wherein the first thickness and the second thickness are different. In some embodiments, the second thickness is larger than the first thickness, thereby forming a step on the sides of the singulated semiconductor packages. In some embodiments, the first partial cut or the second partial cut is performed using a blade having a beveled edge.

<summary>
The invention provides a mobile terminal that can selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) or a wireless local area network (WLAN). The mobile terminal has a first network module (e.g., GSM) for connecting to the WWAN and a second network module (e.g., WiFi) for connecting to the WLAN. The WLAN has an access point that gathers service information (e.g., signal strength, channel information, base station identity codes) from neighboring WWAN base stations and transmits it to the mobile terminal. When the mobile terminal is connected to the WLAN, the first network module is off, and the second network module is on. When the signal level of the WLAN becomes low, the mobile terminal turns on the first network module and uses the service information to select a serving base station in the WWAN. If the first network module fails to connect to the serving base station using the service information, it can scan the frequency channels or start an all channels scanning procedure. The mobile terminal can switch between the WWAN and WLAN at any status, such as "call set up" or "idle".</summary>

The invention provides a process for manufacturing multilayered electrical components, such as capacitors, by forming electrodes and electrical components on decals, stacking them to create sub-assemblies, and then firing the stacks to create the final product. This process simplifies manufacturing by eliminating steps such as cutting and metallizing, and allows for the production of smaller parts with lower voltage ratings and no shape limitations. It also enhances in-process inspection and eliminates stress cracks caused by cutting. The process is adaptable to other electronic ceramic devices, such as multilayer ferrite inductors and multilayer substrates with buried metal circuitry.

The present invention relates to a hierarchical lattice structure comprising unit cells of various sizes connected together to form a lightweight lattice structure with improved specific stiffness and strength. The lattice structure can be used as the core of sandwich panel structures and has many applications, including use in minimum weight structural applications, impact or blast load mitigation, cross flow heat exchange, and armors with high ballistic resistance. The lattice structure can be manufactured using various methods, including injection molding, investment casting, and metal textile lay-up techniques.

The process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons involves two stages: a wet gasification stage and a dry gasification stage. In the wet gasification stage, coal is gasified to produce a combustion gas at elevated pressure comprising H2 and CO, which is then enriched with H2 to produce an H2-enriched gas. In the dry gasification stage, coal is gasified to produce a synthesis gas precursor at elevated pressure comprising H2 and CO. The H2-enriched gas is mixed with the synthesis gas precursor to provide a synthesis gas for hydrocarbon synthesis. The combustion gas is also used to generate power. The process includes synthesising hydrocarbons from the synthesis gas in one or more Fischer-Tropsch hydrocarbon synthesis stages, producing one or more hydrocarbon product streams and a Fischer-Tropsch tail gas which includes CO2, CO and H2. The process also includes treating the Fischer-Tropsch tail gas to remove CO2 and H2, and recycling the H2 to the Fischer-Tropsch hydrocarbon synthesis stages. The process further includes treating the synthesis gas precursor or the synthesis gas to remove sulphur and/or CO2, and feeding a portion of the CO2 obtained from the treatment of synthesis gas precursor or synthesis gas and/or from the treatment of the Fischer-Tropsch tail gas to a combustor used to generate power from the second portion of the combustion gas to act as a temperature moderating agent. The process also includes treating exhaust gas from the waste heat recovery stage waste heat boiler, comprising predominantly CO2 and water, to remove the water, leaving a CO2 exhaust stream which may be sequestrated or captured for further use.

The present invention provides a method for preparing a solid device using an oxide superconducting material with improved surface properties. The method involves forming a blocking film on the surface of the superconducting material to prevent oxygen removal, and then controlling the oxygen concentration in the surface portion. A photo-CVD method is used to form a film that uniformly coats the micro-holes in the surface, and the film is then converted to a dense insulating material. The oxygen concentration in the surface portion is controlled by solid phase diffusion from the film into the superconducting material. The blocking film can be used as a passivation film or as an insulating film in a Josephson element. The superconducting material can be in tablet or thin film form, and various methods can be used to form the thin film. The oxide superconducting material has a general formula of (A1-xBx)yCuzOw, where A and B are specific elements, and x, y, z, and w are within certain ranges. The blocking film can be formed from various insulating materials or metals that become insulating when oxidized. After forming the film, oxygen is added to the surface portion by ion injection or hot oxidation, and the entire body is heat treated to position the oxygen in the appropriate atom location. The method results in a highly reliable surface utilizing device, such as a Josephson element, with long-term stability.

The invention is an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination. It consists of a base plate, support columns, a top deck plate, a support bar, a clamp bar, posts, a saddle bar, a threaded member, a hand nut, a detent mechanism, a lower clamp mechanism, and a foam sample. The foam sample is placed between the support bar and the clamp bar, and the lower clamp mechanism secures it in place. The hand nut, when rotated, moves the threaded member and the saddle bar, raising the foam sample. A razor blade is used to cut off a thin slice of the foam sample at the desired thickness. The apparatus allows for precise, parallel cuts to be made on the foam sample, preserving the cell structure for microscopic examination. The method involves placing the foam sample in the apparatus, securing it with the lower clamp mechanism, rotating the hand nut to raise the sample, cutting off a slice with a razor blade, and repeating the process for different thicknesses. The apparatus and method allow for the preparation of foam samples with parallel cut surfaces, preserving the cell structure for examination.

The invention is a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer, such as an on-bottom seismometer, with respect to the vertical and for leveling its seismic motion detectors. The apparatus comprises a pendulum formed by a geophone or other seismic motion detector suspended at the end of a shaft protruding from a spherical ball rotating in an annular seat. A spring-loaded plunger is positioned above the ball and restrained from contact with its surface by a pin connected to a linearly acting solenoid. When the seismometer is deployed, the pendulum action of the invention automatically levels the geophone or other seismic motion detector. After the seismometer has stabilized, the solenoid is activated, pulling the pin from the plunger which, under the force of its spring, extends to contact the surface of the ball, locking the geophone or other seismic motion detector in its position. The angle of inclination assumed by the seismometer can then be determined by measuring the acute angle formed by the ball, shaft, and geophone or other seismic motion detector in their locked position and a surface known to be vertical when the seismometer is in its normal, up-right position. The invention also provides a rigid connection from the geophone or other seismic motion detector through the support means to the frame of the seismometer, ensuring good acoustic coupling between the ocean bottom and the detector.

The humidity sensing element of the present invention comprises a first electron conductive electrode, a porous coating of dielectric thereon, minute particles of electron conductive material deposited in the interstices of the porosity of the dielectric, a second electron conductive electrode pervious to moisture vapor and disposed on the dielectric coating on the opposite side thereof from the first electrode, an ion-forming material in the dielectric commonly contacting the particles and the second electrode and reducing the porosity of the dielectric, the impedance between the electrodes varying generally linearly with relation to the relative humidity of the surrounding gaseous atmosphere in a suitable range of interest when excited by a suitable alternating current voltage. The first electrode is formed from commercially pure anodizable metal, an anodized layer thereof forms the dielectric coating, the minute particles deposited therein are metal and the ion-forming material contacting them reduces the porosity of the dielectric, the impedance between the electrodes is a capacitance-resistance combination, and the second electrode is formed by vacuum deposition of metal from a plated hot filament onto the anodized layer. The preferred humidity sensing element has the first electrode formed from 99.4% pure aluminum which is anodized to a thickness in the range of about 0.02 to 0.08 millimeters, atom-sized nickel particles are deposited in the interstices of the anodized dielectric while it is dry and unsealed by vacuum deposition from a hot nickel-plated filament in a quantity equivalent to an amount calculated to deposit on a smooth non-porous surface a layer between 5 and 10 Angstrom units thick, and the element is suitable for exciting for sensing by an alternating current sine wave voltage in the order of 10 Hertz for optimizing the temperature effects on the linearity of the decreasing impedance with increasing relative humidity relationship of the element. The method of manufacturing the humidity sensing element comprises the steps of coating at least a portion of a first electron conductive electrode with a porous coating of dielectric, depositing minute particles of electron conductive material in the interstices of the porosity of the dielectric, commonly contacting the particles in the interstices by means of an ion-forming material, and forming a second electron conductive electrode contacting the ion-forming material and pervious to moisture vapor and disposed on the dielectric coating on the opposite side thereof from the first electrode whereby the impedance between the electrodes varies generally linearly with relation to the relative humidity of the surrounding gaseous atmosphere in a suitable range of interest when excited by a suitable alternating current voltage. The preferred method of manufacturing includes forming the first electrode from commercially pure aluminum

The motor assembly of the present invention comprises a motor, a gear train, and a force transmission structure. The force transmission structure includes a drive plate with a Y-shaped mounting hole and a shaft with a Y-shaped toothed portion fittingly received in the mounting hole. The drive plate is driven by the gear train and rotates the shaft via the mating of the mounting hole and the toothed portion, which reduces vibration and noise and increases torque capacity.

The present invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver in a wireless communication system. The system comprises an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem, and a baseband subsystem. The radio frequency subsystem includes a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator, while the baseband subsystem includes a free running counter coupled to both oscillators. The free running counter generates a mobile time reference using the high frequency oscillator during an active mode and maintains the mobile time reference using the low frequency oscillator during an idle mode. The mobile time reference is constantly running and has an accuracy of approximately 32 nanoseconds. The invention also includes a method of generating a mobile time reference, which involves providing a high frequency clock, providing a low frequency clock, generating a mobile time reference using the high frequency clock, maintaining the mobile time reference using the low frequency clock when the high frequency clock is not available, and continuing to generate the mobile time reference using the high frequency clock when it is again available.

The invention describes a custom-fitted helmet liner made of elastic thermoplastic sheets with hollow spherical protuberances, arranged in layers with flat portions in contact. The liner is fitted by heating it to a plastic state, placing it on the wearer's head, and allowing it to cool and solidify. The open, unfilled protuberances allow for compliance and easy fitting, while the liner can be refitted for different head sizes within its range. The liner is secured to the helmet shell using fasteners and is covered with a fabric lining for comfort.

The invention is a multiorifice structure made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods interspaced with cylindrical members, with each successive layer of rods disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly. The fused assembly is then cut into thin wafers, creating angularly disposed passageways that increase in angle as a function of their distance from the center of the structure.

The invention provides methods for manufacturing semiconductor devices, particularly insulated gate field effect transistors (MOSFETs) with lightly doped drain (LDD) structures. The methods aim to improve the controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall, enable low temperature processing, and prevent degradation of transconductance and increased resistances due to hot-carrier injection into the oxide portion.

In a first embodiment, an oxide film is used as an etching stopper, and a polycrystalline silicon layer is anisotropically etched using reactive ion etching (RIE) to leave a portion on the gate sidewall. This improves the controllability of the width of the polycrystalline silicon on the gate sidewall and prevents the source/drain from being etched away.

In a second embodiment, the width of the polycrystalline silicon portion on the gate sidewall is increased by making the gate electrode thicker. This allows for easier removal of the polycrystalline silicon on the sidewall after ion injection.

In a third embodiment, an oxide film is formed on the gate sidewall using an insulating film on the gate as a mask. The high concentration region of the source/drain is then formed by injecting impurity ions using the oxide film on the gate sidewall and the insulating film on the gate as a mask. After removing the oxide film on the gate sidewall, the low concentration region of the source/drain is formed by injecting impurity ions.

In a fourth embodiment, the low concentration region is formed by injecting impurity ions using the insulating film on the gate as a mask. An oxide film is then formed on the gate sidewall using the insulating film on the gate as a mask. The high concentration region is formed by injecting impurity ions using this oxide film and the insulating film on the gate as a mask.

In a fifth embodiment, the oxide film portion on the gate sidewall is formed of a high melting point metal or a silicide of such a metal. This allows hot carriers to be derived through the gate electrode, preventing the transconductance from being degraded by hot-carrier injection.

In a sixth embodiment, a conductive or polycrystalline semiconductor layer is formed on an insulating film on the gate electrode. This layer is then anisotropically etched using RIE to leave a portion on the gate sidewall. The end point of etching can be detected easily, and the width of the portion on the gate sidewall can be controlled precisely.

In a seventh embodiment, the gate electrode and/or the source/drain region is silicided. This reduces the sheet resistance of the source/drain region and prevents the transconductance from being

The present invention provides an enhanced radio telephone that can be used as an improved IP telephone when connected to a PC. Unlike conventional IP telephones, the enhanced radio telephone performs speech coding and decoding, reducing the computational burden on the PC and allowing for a lower-performance, less expensive computer to be used. The enhanced radio telephone also provides a convenient handset and reduces echo problems associated with conventional IP telephones. The enhanced radio telephone can be switched between wireless and IP-telephone modes of operation manually or automatically, and calls can be initiated using either the PC or the enhanced radio telephone. In some embodiments, the enhanced radio telephone also handles network communication, further reducing the burden on the PC.

The present invention relates to devices for converting electrical power, pressurized water, or other useful work from surface waves on a water body. The device comprises one or more gas-filled submerged containers with a fixed depth rigid end and an opposing movable end connected by a flexible, reinforced, gas-tight bellows or diaphragm. The movable end is connected to a hydraulic or pneumatic pumping means, mechanical drive means, or electrical drive means. The device may also include a floating surface vent buoy or expandable bellows connected to the submerged container to enhance energy capture. The device may be oriented vertically, horizontally, or in any other orientation to capture both heave and surge wave energy. The device may also include wave reflection and focusing means to increase energy capture efficiency. The device may be moored at a relatively fixed depth or adjusted for tides or severe sea-states. The device may also include a force multiplier or leveraged connecting means to increase stroke and drive force.

<summary>
The invention pertains to a scraped surface heat exchanger blade that facilitates mounting onto a drive shaft using a pin type connection. The blade has a first side with a first L-shaped locking track and a second side with a second L-shaped locking track. The first track has a first entry track and a first intermediate track, while the second track has a second entry track and a second intermediate track. The blade is mounted by inserting it at an angle between the inner and outer fingers of a pin, sliding it along the tracks until the inner finger aligns with a mounting hole, and then pivoting the blade to an installation position. The blade is restrained from longitudinal movement in one direction by interference between the pin and the tracks on both sides of the blade. The entry tracks on the first and second sides have different widths to ensure the blade is installed with the correct side facing up. The blade can only be removed by raising it and sliding it off the pin. The tracks on both sides of the blade preserve the structural rigidity of the blade while reducing wear. The invention provides a method for mounting a blade to a scraped surface heat exchanger drive shaft by pivotal connection with a mounting pin, using tracks on both sides of the blade to interfere with the pin and lock the blade against longitudinal movement in one direction while permitting pivoting movement relative to the drive shaft.</summary>

The invention relates to a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a production/packaging machine. The detection process involves using a camera to scan an image of multiple cigarettes in the magazine, evaluating the image using image-processing software, and generating an error signal if the image deviates from a reference image or value. The elimination process involves actuating an ejecting unit to remove a plurality of cigarettes in an ejecting zone assigned to the unit when a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected. The ejecting unit has a front wall and a rear wall of different sizes and contours to prevent jamming. The apparatus includes a camera, image-processing device, and at least one ejecting unit with a housing, carriage, and ejector. The ejector has a front wall and rear wall connected by a connecting rod, and a housing-like device to prevent cigarettes from dropping into the ejector region. The cigarette magazine has multiple ejecting zones, each assigned to an ejecting unit, and evaluation zones, each assigned to an ejecting zone. The camera scans an image of all evaluation zones, and the image-processing device evaluates each zone separately. If a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected in an evaluation zone, the corresponding ejecting unit is actuated with a time delay to eject the cigarettes in the assigned ejecting zone. The ejecting unit can also be actuated manually or at regular intervals for sampling.

The invention provides a simplified connection system for high voltage power cables, using a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections, with factory pretesting, reduced installation time and cost, and simplified field testing. The interface components do not include any gas or oil, preventing leaks or explosions. The stress cone design and dimensions are generally applicable, with the only variation being the diameter of the cable or apparatus entrance.

The invention relates to a fixing mechanism for a tool used in machining, such as milling, drilling, or turning, where the tool is secured to a frame and the frame is secured to a tool holder in a machine tool. The fixing mechanism uses a combination of curved surfaces on the tool frame and tool holder to facilitate easy and secure mounting and removal of the tool. The curved surfaces allow for a simple mounting movement and transmit machining forces between the tool frame and tool holder.

The present invention provides methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits with high efficiency and low electromagnetic interference (EMI). A switching regulator circuit is modified to create multiple circuit paths carrying current in opposite directions to cancel out radiated noise. Additional terminal lines are provided to absorb any remaining EMI. This allows for the production of large amounts of current needed to drive large displays, such as those on the Apple iPhone, without the typical penalties associated with EMI or noise. The invention is particularly useful in chip on glass (COG) implementations where an integrated circuit (IC) is located on one side of the glass used in displays.

<summary>
A power system includes a battery with multiple cells and a controller that balances and charges the cells to achieve a target drive range. The controller determines the maximum capacity of each cell, the common voltage needed for each cell to support the target drive range, the charge time for the battery pack, and the resistive circuitry activation time for each cell. If the pack charge time is greater than the maximum of the resistive circuitry activation times, the controller activates the resistive circuitry for each cell and enables the battery charger. Once the resistive circuitry activation time for each cell has expired, the controller deactivates the resistive circuitry and determines whether the battery pack charge time has expired. If yes, the controller disables the battery charger, and the cells of the battery pack have been balanced/charged to a target voltage sufficient to support the desired drive range.
</summary>

The invention is an AC-to-DC converter for lamps that provides constant brightness, no low or high frequency flicker, and no electromagnetic radiation, reducing eye fatigue and protecting health. It includes input protection, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, lamp, start circuit, control circuit, biasing circuit, sampling circuit, output protection circuit, feedback and dimming circuit, and input monitor circuit. The converter uses a topology like Flyback and an IC controller to regulate output voltage at a constant value, with dimming achieved through a potentiometer. The power supply can be used in various applications, including lighting, computers, TVs, and power tools.

The system controls window treatments to minimize or eliminate sun glare based on photosensor readings, using a closed loop control algorithm with a dead-band. The system only changes window treatment settings when the incident light level on the photosensors is outside of the dead-band. The system employs a low sampling rate numerical integration of the light level error to reduce the frequency of window treatment movements. The system employs a variable control setpoint or threshold based on the sun angle to correctly address the glare control problem.

The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has made significant strides in enhancing aviation security since September 11, 2001, including deploying federal screeners, implementing explosives detection systems, and expanding the Federal Air Marshal Service. However, TSA faces long-term challenges such as improving the efficiency and effectiveness of aviation security, managing its workforce, and building a results-oriented culture within the Department of Homeland Security.

The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) have different definitions of lobbying, which can affect who registers and what they report under LDA. LDA requires tracking contacts with a much broader set of federal officials than the IRC definitions when lobbying contacts are made about nonlegislative matters, but the IRC definitions potentially cover contacts with more levels of executive branch officials than LDA covers when those contacts are about legislation.

<summary>GAO has been advocating for strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade, with OMB implementing a government-wide program in 2005. Despite progress, agencies still manage only a small fraction of their spending through strategic sourcing, with services being particularly under-addressed. Leading companies have successfully applied strategic sourcing to services, using tactics tailored to the complexity and supplier landscape of each service category. GAO recommends that agencies adopt leading practices, increase strategic sourcing spending, and target high-spend categories like services.</summary>

The current surface transportation programs in the U.S. are not effectively addressing key challenges such as increasing congestion and growing freight demand. The federal role in these programs is unclear, and many programs lack links to needs or performance. The goals of these programs are numerous and sometimes conflicting, making the federal role unclear. Most highway, transit, and safety grant funds are distributed through formulas that have only an indirect relationship to needs and many have no relationship to performance or outcomes. Mechanisms to link programs to goals appear insufficient, and surface transportation programs often do not employ the best tools and approaches to improve results and emphasize return on investment. The solvency of the federal surface transportation program is at risk due to increased spending from the fund without commensurate increases in revenues.

The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is responsible for managing the National Airspace System (NAS) and funding its operations through a combination of excise taxes and general fund revenues. The current funding structure has raised concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency, as well as the potential need for alternative funding options. FAA's budget and Trust Fund revenue data, as well as forecasts and aviation activity data, were analyzed to assess the link between workload increases and Trust Fund revenue increases. The experience of foreign air navigation service providers was also examined to identify potential alternative funding options and criteria for comparing them. Additionally, the advantages and disadvantages of authorizing FAA to use debt financing for capital projects were reviewed.

The Department of Defense (DOD) has been working to identify servicemembers and civilians who may have been exposed to chemical or biological substances during tests conducted under Project 112 since 2003. However, DOD has not conducted a comprehensive cost-benefit analysis to determine the feasibility of continuing to search for additional individuals potentially exposed during Project 112 tests.

The U.S. government is working to combat firearms trafficking to Mexico, with ATF and ICE as the primary agencies involved. ATF traces firearms seized in Mexico and found to have originated in the U.S., while ICE investigates and prosecutes cases involving arms trafficking to Mexico.

The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal grant program managed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) to build a national infrastructure for facilitating the interstate exchange of criminal history and other relevant records. NCHIP has awarded over $438 million in grants since 1995 to states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories to improve their criminal history records and establish automated capabilities that enhance participation in national criminal history records systems. The primary systems supported by NCHIP include the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS), the National Crime Information Center (NCIC), the Interstate Identification Index (III), and the Integrated Automated Fingerprint Identification System (IAFIS). NCHIP funds have been used by states to improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records, as well as to enhance participation in national systems. The use of NCHIP funds by states has been tracked by BJS using six spending categories, with the majority of funds being used for NICS/III/criminal records improvements and disposition reporting improvements. The case-study states of California, Maryland, Mississippi, Texas, and West Virginia have used NCHIP funds to improve their criminal history records and enhance participation in national systems. The priority states of Maine, Mississippi, New Mexico, Vermont, and West Virginia have also made progress in automating their criminal history records with the help of NCHIP funds. None of the 50 states have used NCHIP funds to develop or implement a ballistics registration system.

EPA uses incineration as a cleanup method at some Superfund sites, with three incinerators currently in operation. These incinerators have safety features and are monitored to ensure safe operation, but EPA has not consistently implemented all planned oversight measures. GAO recommends that EPA implement guidance for inspecting Superfund incinerators and document lessons learned from each site to share with others.
